If you never played this in your childhood, your parents probably didn't love you or you weren't old enough to comprehend how awesome this was/is, Now you can experience it whether you played it back in the day or are new to this!! Have fun building awesome rollercoasters that visitors are to afraid to get on, that took you an hour to create! You can also build death traps! do you remember those visitors to afraid to go on you really cool rollercoaster that took you forever to make!?! why don't you just go kill them off by build a rollercoaster that launches them into the air and then they hit the ground in a ball of flames! That will teach them next...well it will teach the other visitors!! In conclusion this game is awesome and cheap and it has the same stuff back in the day! i give this 1,000 visitors and a Park Rating of over 900!!! or 10/10

												In a post-apocalyptic world, you are the manager of a random (more or less) spot of land with the ability to instantly change the terrain and build Disneyland rides, and an endless population of white, brown-haired males that need to eat, drink, go to the bathroom, and be entertained. In order to survive in this unforgiving world, you must ask yourself difficult, sometimes painful, questions. Such as:Should I create a legit coaster or something to turn people into cherry pudding?Why will nobody go on my roller coaster I spent the last 2 hours making?And, most crucial of all...How did I lose all my damn money?!Roller Coaster Tycoon. Your Decisions will shape the amusement park around youFor real, if you didn't play this game (or one of the sequels) as a kid, something went wrong in the system. Sorry to break it to ya.

number of helpful: 102 of 104 people (98%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Roller Coaster Tycoon: Deluxe is an isometric tycoon game where you manage your own them park. Not just one, but each of the game's 70+ scenario is a different park. The scenarios get broken into four different categories: original, loopy landscapes, corkscrew follies, real life parks and extra parks. There is no fast forward button, so you're stuck going at the same pace. A game year would be an hour of real life time and several scenarios go between 3 - 4 hours. Each scenario has success conditions like have X amount of people in your park by year 3 with a rating of over 600. Others are more complex like double the park value without taking out a loan. Then after the time expires, you can keep playing if you'd like. There is around 210+ hours of game in these scenarios.As the manager of the theme park, you can plop down rides. From there, you can paint them, change their music and entrances. Even change different options on each one like how many times does a Ferris wheel go around? You'll build walkways to get to places and lanes to get to ride entrances. Without lanes no one will stand in line. The longer the lanes, the longer people need to wait in line. You can even raise and lower terrain, add water all at a price.The joy here is designing your own tracks. Roller coasters, go carts, flumes, slides and every other type of track. The game comes with premade tracks, but you can design your own as you go. Couture them to your land, have them dive into tunnels, over walkways. Heck design them to launch the trains off the track to kill people. This is your game, you do what you want. Just don't expect anyone to ever ride a crashed roller coaster again. You can even take away bridges to drown your patrons.Building the tracks is fun, there are a lot of roller coasters to chose from. Standing steel, sitting steel, inverted steel, wooden, twisting steel, diving coasters that can drop at 90 degree angles, hanging steel and far too many others to list. Different rides have different needs. Some need to be a smoother ride with less sharp turns. Others like the wild mouse roller coaster need sharp turns everywhere. The only down side is you make it as you go. There is no way to construct your perfect coaster, then add it into the game like you can with Roller Coaster Tycoon 2. You can still save any track design to your premade tracks to use at a different time.Each ride has stats broken into three categories, excitement, intensity and nausea. Every patron has their own stats. If they're looking for something calm, intense or exciting. If your ride is 18 loops back to back with an excitement stat of 23, but an intensity level of 23, don't expect many riders. If rides are too gentle, like kid slides and bumper cars, you'll hear about it. You need to pace things, blend gentle rides next to thrill rides. The more nauseating the ride, the more people will throw up unless you have enough benches outside the ride exit for them to sit down on.If someone throws up, you'll need to hire handymen to clean it up. They'll also water gardens, mow grass, empty trash cans and so on. You can even set the land they cover. When your rides break down, you will need mechanics not just to fix them, but inspect them. This ensures rides run with less down time and no one randomly dies due to brakes cutting out and one trains smashes into another. There are security guards for when patrons get too angry. Costumed characters can get hired to keep people happy while they're waiting in line.Decorations also boost patron enjoyment. Plant flowers near walkways, statues near lines, plants and trees next to rides. Its all up to you. Decorations next to a ride will slightly increase its excitement value. For the most part, designing a ride track under, over and next to either itself or a different ride will boost its excitement level. With enough effort, you can make a merry go round into an exciting ride, but its easier to make anything else in the park exciting.There is a thought view of everyone in the park, so you can determine what the people want. Are they hungry? Thirsty? Sick? Do they need to 'go?' Well then build food stalls, drink stalls, benches and bathrooms. There are a lot of different stalls and you can set the price on everything in the park including setting all your drink stalls to charge the same price. Not just that, but there are plenty of merchandise stalls full of things for your patrons to buy when they're happy enough.So how do you get different stalls, rides, coasters and decorations? You devote X amount of dollars each month to ride development. Minimum, medium, maximum or no funding at all. This will be how quickly you'll unlock something for the park you're managing. There are even check boxes for what you want to research. Gentle rides, thrill rides, roller coasters, shops & stalls, scenery and ride improvements. Ride improvements are simple things like putting a wooden roller coaster train backward.The game is very flexible when it comes to finances. Each scenario will usually start you off with a hefty bank loan that has minimal interest. You can get a bank loan up to a certain amount, depending on the scenario. Having money always lets you keep playing and growing. If you outgrow your park, then just buy land tile by tile. Its a little tedious, but whatever. Sometimes you need to buy rights to have your coasters go over roads, because you can't buy the land itself. While you can charge money for each ride, you can also make them all free with a park entry fee. Some scenarios force you to do certain things financially. The restrictions, coupled with the different parks make it interesting. Instead of just having the perfect park over and over again.On top of that, there is promotion for your park. Pay X amount for park or ride marketing for X number of weeks. Free ride vouchers, free food, half price entry for the park and so on. Its all to draw people in when you need it. Without patrons you can't make money, but all you really need are fresh rides. Old rides start breaking down more often. People visit them less in favor of newer rides. No one wants to spend $4 to ride your 3 year old roller coaster and so on.The patrons themselves seem pretty dumb. They'll walk in circles, so I've found straight lines are the best way to get them around the park. In one of the expansions of the deluxe version, there is a no entrance sign that you can post. People can't enter, but they can come out. Its helpful, especially for scenarios that start you in a park that has dozens of paths. Patrons get lost and start destroying things.I've owned Roller Coaster Tycoon for 15+ years. Its one of the first PC games that I bought with my own money after playing the 3 scenario demo. Not just that, but then I proceeded to buy all the expansion packs. I've completed the game on 5 different computers. I am big into management and tycoon games and I think this is one of the best if not the best.Even though a lot of people enjoy Roller Coaster Tycoon 2 more for its much larger parks, I still like the original better. I still feel its the best management game, but I can understand that the game can play itself at some point. You can walk away for two hours and come back with the scenario completed. Unless of course a roller coaster explodes or something. Its a relaxing low stress game, even if you're put in charge of a place that people could die... and you can kill them.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
												One of the best PC games ever made. I originally got this game back in 1999 when it was first released, and 16 years later it's still fun to play. The Steam version also comes with both expansion packs.The game had amazing optimization for its time. It ran smooth on a 400 MHz Celeron, even with a huge park. Chris Sawyer is a programming genius for making the game run so well. It still works on modern systems too, and runs flawless on Windows 8.1 and Windows 10.There is a large variety of different rides to build, and you can build your own roller coaster designs. There are also lots of different scenarios to play and unlock, each with their own goals.The only downsides to this game are the lack of mod support, and that there is no sandbox mode. There are, however, a few scenarios with unlimited money, though they still have goals you have to reach, and failing them will result in your park being permanently closed.Still, it's an amazing game, even to this day. I would recommend if you enjoy building simulators and/or theme park management games, or just for the nostalgia if you played it years ago.

												A classic! I just wish the resolution options were up to date.2014-05-26: The game has a few shortcomings, being as old as it is. Some things I think might make the game more up-to-date are:- Widescreen support- Buildings where staff spend their stand-by time, instead of having your staff trekking all around the park. This applies to technicians in particular.- Ability to choose elevation when placing buildings- Mouse wheel zooming- More/improved customer/visitor statistics and information overviews- Better feedback on game mechanics like customer happiness, popularity and satisfaction.- More detailed economic insight/control, including salaries, maintenence costs and infrastructure.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												As a game from my childhood, I may or may not hold some bias in favor of this game.However, this will not be evident in my review. Let's answer some questions."What is this game?"Rollercoaster Tycoon is a franchise where the player becomes an amusement park owner with the power to create tracks, customize everything from the terrain and decor to the ride names and colors, and even charging people to use the BATHROOM. Great idea. Think the sims, but without families and more workers and rides."Any ACTUAL skills I can get from this game?"Yes. Balancing out a budget is seen by the money amount you are given in loans. These allow you to buy rides, stands, construct in general, advertise, et cetera. These loans CAN be paid off so you can run the park and not have your money taken away every month for loans. Also, there is keeping things cleaned/organized. The park gets awards based on how you run it, ranging from "Safest Park in The Country" to "Worst Looking Park". In order to keep good PR, you want to hire some handymen who sweep up all the vomit and trash people leave lying around."Anything popular come out of this game?"I WANT TO GET OFF MR.BONES' WILD RIDEI WANT TO GET OFF MR.BONES' WILD RIDEI WANT TO GET OFF MR.BONES' WILD RIDEI WANT TO GET OFF MR.BONES' WILD RIDE"Why not just RCT3?"RCT3 is just, eh. It's hard to explain. RCT3 is not a bad game at all, trust me, I own that one as well and its fantastic. But, it will never have the same bouncy feel the early ones do. RCT3 is more calming and orderly. RCT 1 and 2 are bouncy, chaotic, and generally more enjoyable. In the earlier games, you get more of a RCT feel and less of a Sims. The gui in RCT3 even looks like the Sims. Still tho, try both and see which is your cup of tea."DLC?"get out"Any bugs?"The game is being updated constantly due to being on steam, mainly in language support from what I've seen, but that doesn't mean its lost some if its old bugs. Sometimes, mechanics pay no attention to rides and they just get fixed on their own by some means. Guests still just wander off park when you delete the path they're on instead of finding another path. RCT was made in 1999, so its not really a suprise when these things happen. You just have to push them in the right direction and it's all figured out (by that I mean pick them up and throw them at the ride's enterance until they get it RIGHT)."Is the music good?"Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ yes.You can set music differently for each ride, so if you don't appreciate one song, just pick another!----------------------------------------------------------------------------Basically, get this game. You will not regret it.

Posted: November 28, 2015
												As a kid I would always start off every park I made by hiring 5 or so handymen, in preparation for the onslaught of puke and overfilled garbage bins the park would soon be plagued with. And yet, I always made sure to remove the "mow grass" from their job descriptions; keeping it meant your handymen would be off mowing instead of doing everything else. And yet, I always felt bad for the grass; was it really right to neglect it, simply because of a minor inconveniance to my park? So I always hired one more than I needed, and made his only job being to mow grass. 35$ monthly, earned solely through his sweat and his lawnmower. Off in the unexplored regions of the park, where nobody can even see the grass he's mowing. I always made sure to give him a absurd name.Around 10 years later, I find myself tracking Dorkle's adventure through the wilderness, chronicling his neverending battle against the grass, as I try to find a good spot for the next ferris wheel.10/10 would relive cherised childhood memories again.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												A charming and timeless game, Rollercoaster Tycoon will continue to please the young at heart and theme park fans today. The Pre-Rendered graphics still hold up to this day better than most games of it's time. The most impressive thing about this game is the development of it. It was programmed by one man; Chris Sawyer. The highlight of this game is seeing your guests come off your ride enjoying themselves. It is a very rewarding experience. That's not to say this game is without faults. One of the bigger problems is the limitation of scenery. This was however fixed in the game's sequels, and if we go into nitpicking, there are problems with the janitors only mowing grass (which can be easily fixed by checking a box). These things can be overlooked however and I believe that this entry in the series is by far the most rewarding. I haven't sunk as many hours into this game as the other entries but that doesn't mean I haven't had fun the entire time, grinning like an idiot ear to ear8/10

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												RCT Deluxe is one of those rare old gems that, no matter how much people try, has yet to have a spiritual successor fully recapture its essence or innovate in a meaningful way, and the reason for that is in the game's fundamentally brilliant design: it's a concise, well-balanced blend of extreme customization and structural rigidity, two seemingly-conflicting ideals that are perfectly intertwined. Coaster design, park layouts, scenery, and other aspects offer near-infinite variety, but the isometric view and deceptively simple and intuitive grid system offers a very acute precision to coaster refinement that allows a player to master the art of designing and redesigning coasters.The game's primary focus is on the creation of your very own amusement parks in one of dozens of locations, each with their own distinct goals. To be successful, one must learn how to keep their guests happy by providing them with an assortment of pre-built rides, stalls, and utilities as well as custom roller coasters and other rides that the player must design using a user-friendly ride editing tool. This and other tools offer the player complete control over the ride's track, trains, thematic elements, and price. The player must be considerate of their guests' ride preferences, as every section of track and the overall route will affect three ride statistics: excitement, intensity, and nausea. Learning to design coasters with these stats in mind is a fun and challenging puzzle in itself, and it has a major impact on a park's overall success.Beyond the fundamentals, after the game eases the player into the basics of park management, each new unlocked park objective teaches a new skill and provides new challenges for the player to test their ability to adapt. The absurd amount of campaigns, contents, rides, scenic options, and other items allows for literally hundreds of hours of fun just to get through all the campaigns at least once, and no two feel alike. Furthermore, while certain methodologies and techniques are sometimes encouraged, the game allows for all sorts of individualistic play styles and different approaches to the same hurdles, so it always feels like strategic and creative problem-solving, not memorization or repetition. Challenges are always present, but they are fair and well-crafted in their structure, so you are always encouraged to improve. Visually, the game has aged extremely well, and the sprites and assets all look and function beautifully. The game is coded in Assembly, so modding will likely not be an option, but the game's performance is always top-notch. Be sure to check that this version of the game is compatible with your OS before you buy it, but I would highly recommend this game to anyone. It has superb replayability and is always as fresh and exciting as the first time you played it as a little kid. If anything, it's probably more enjoyable today, given the ability to revisit and appreciate the complexity of the game's design with the mental sharpness that comes with adulthood.Granted, there are occasional small issues with path-finding and staff location assignment as well as the occasional imprecision of the algorithms for calculating ride stats. However, none of these concerns are close to game-breaking, and a bit of extra forethought and experimentation can avoid most if not all of the effects of these, thus the limitations of the game encourage you to work more effectively within those limits. For example, careful planning of main paths, kiosks, queue lines, and facilities can ensure that guests' needs are catered to, and assigning staff locations based on footpath traffic and ride exit access can ensure that rides and paths are always maintained in a timely manner. As of this review, I've clocked over 100 hours into this game, and I absolutely cannot wait for the next 100 hours.My final rating is 9.8 out of 10. This game was a labor of love, and it really shows.

Posted: September 18, 2014
												RollerCoaster Tycoon was a freakin' staple of my childhood.I would spend HOURS building torture devices--I mean roller coasters--that would scare the bajeezus out of Chuck Norris.  Here are some of the high points of the game:--Ability to charge insane prices to use the bathroom.--Drown patrons who dare to complain about the high price of using the toilet.--Practice physics by building rollercoasters that launch people to their deaths (velocity and speed are key).--Employ "Sad Pandas" to entertain people dumb enough to wait in lines for a hedge maze.--Find ducks.  Click on them.--Place a balloon stand and charge $15 for a balloon only to pop it after a patron buys one.It's the simple joy of disgruntled customers that keeps me coming back for more after all these years.Buy it.  You won't be disappointed.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												This is another game that I had on a CD in which my little brother used to throw around as a frisbee. Which therein made me buy a virtual copy so he couldn't touch it. I have spent countless upon countless hours on this game. My oldest brother who rarely played video games played this. My sister who never plays video games played this. Even my dad spent half an hour trying to figure the game out before saying he had something better to do. RollerCoaster Tycoon may have been the first park simulator game (arguably). RollerCoaster Tycoon is a park simulator game (an old one I should add). You are a manager of a park and call all the shots. When you first start on a map, there may be trees in your way or uneven land preventing you from building properly. Not a problem. Trees can be removed and dirt can be manipulated at your whim (for a nice price of course :)! Alternatively, you may build underground. Basic rides such as a merry go round, track-carts and a pirate ship may be available. You may further your parks research and choose specifically what you want to be researched.I personally go after the thrill rides first and try to acquire go-karts as they are a money maker! My first piece of advice would be to go to the research tab and ensure that you are maximizing (the research) and choose what you would like to be discovered. If you don't like my idea, heck makes some new roller coaster, scenery or even a new food kiosk! The rides get pretty crazy after some research and some new insane roller coasters (like suspended ones) come out. Be mindful of your designs. Some guests don't like rides that cost too much, are too long, are too short, are too intense or not intense enough. I haven't quite figured out the scheme to build a successful roller coaster but I found simple concepts that use gravity instead of using manual rails to get your roller coaster to a height is preferred. Some types of roller coasters (or rides like the log flume for instance) give only a certain amount of flexibility regarding their construction. Some coasters allow for tight turns while some need extra wide turns. Some (like the steel roller coasters) can do helix's and loops! Information kiosks are also available to sell your customers umbrellas and maps of your park. Additional scenery items can also be placed by the player (and unlocked as mentioned) such as trees, gardens, statues, fountains, benches and even garbage cans. Benches by exits of thrilling rides are exceptionally needed as some guests may have to puke. While sitting down, they slowly recover and you don't have to pay as much for an extra handy man. There are service staff that can be hired, most notably mechanics and handymen. Handymen will keep your park clean and will water the gardens whereas mechanics do inspections on rides and fix them as needed. Guests and rides in the park can be clicked on to get feedback (as in was it fun, what is this person thinking, what is this person thinking about this particular ride etc...). Almost anything can also be renamed (including guests) and admission costs to get into the park can be modified. Parks come in different sizes, shapes, colors and location. RCT works off a grid system making it quite easy to build what you need to build. The graphics are not quite outdated but will be bothersome to a few. A full screen resolution is available and should work on most to all monitors. I think the game play will outweigh the graphics on this one. Sounds are pretty varied except for the screams coming from the people on the rides and the noise of the rides themselves.The game was pretty big back in the day, still sort of is. It may take a bit of time to build up and get your park to a steady standard. To some, that wait is definitely worth it. (Game rating back in the day 8.2/10)RATING : 7.1/10 Gameplay B Story / Campaign B Visuals / User Interface B- Sounds / Music C+ Replay-ability B Overall  B

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Where to begin? RollerCoaster Tycoon is arguably the best tycoon game of all time. The game's development was mostly credited to only one man (Chris Sawyer), and was released in 1999. There were four games that defined my childhood. The Sims, Age of Empires II, Dungeon Keeper 2, and this.RollerCoaster Tycoon truly gives you the power to make exactly the kind of amusement park you want to build. Even in the scenarios, it largely feels like a free building game; the game does not ask you to do anything you don't want to do. For example, instead of asking you to build a park based on nothing but rollercoasters like some games might have implemented, Rollercoaster Tycoon simply plops you down on a plot of land and basically says, "Get this many guests and have a good park rating in three years. Have fun and buh-bye!" This game should be truly applauded for being a tycoon game that is not only great fun, but never turns into a chore by forcing you into situations where you feel you're only doing something to beat a level. It gives you an end goal, and it's up to you, the player, to decide exactly how you'll get there.The game allows you to build your own rollercoaster, water slide, log flume, monorail, railroad (and many more) designs from scratch, which gives you endless possibilities in each level (and you will be playing levels over and over again simply for the fun of doing them multiple ways). You can build these rides around one another, underground, over water...there are few limitations. You can also decide what color themes each ride has (or not), even down to making each car in a rollercoaster train a different color. Also, put shops and food stalls around your park and decide how much to charge. You can even charge for guests to use the bathroom, bringing out the greedy capitalist in each of us (I usually make a profit over running costs with my bathrooms, charging just $0.10 per visit).You can even name guests and track them, which brings another level of fun to an already ridiculously great game. Read a guest's thoughts, pick him up and drop him in front of a ride you think he'll like, see what things he's bought from your park that are in his inventory. Hey, you can even drop him in a lake if he's so angry he's potentially messing with your park rating and drown him. It's up to you!RollerCoaster Tycoon is also, in my opinion, better than its sequels. Other than some rides not being available in some levels, it will never revoke your abilities. In RollerCoaster Tycoon 2, there were levels where you had to meet a scenario goal without charging any entry fee for your park, for example, which only ended up taking freedom from the player's hands while pushing itself into the "chore tycoon" category. RollerCoaster Tycoon never crosses that line.In summary, RollerCoaster Tycoon is a fantastic classic game that is perfect as it is. While the graphics may be simplistic by today's standards, it would be simply ignorant to pass up the game because of it. This game is fun, relaxing, rewarding, timeless, and close to flawless. If you don't yet own this game, pick it up. Otherwise, the only one who is missing out is you. ;)

number of helpful: 15 of 15 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												Rollercoaster Tycoon: Deluxe is a classic. A classic that I grew up with, and was amongst the very first games I've played in my life, so it was an instant buy for me, alongside RCT2.Here, like the games after it, you manage a theme park, and try to keep the rating as high as possible, and basically keep your visitors happy. (And if you so wish drown those who don't like your park, just to set an example)It's a fairly simple, and straight forward game that you can sink many, many hours into trying to manage your park, create the ultimate rollercoasters, and keep profit up at the same time. This game, unlike it's successor Rollercoaster Tycoon 2, has unlockable scenario's. You start with several scenario's, and work your way up (or down) from that, trying to get to the very bottom of the list. There's three lists of unlockable scenario's. One for the vanilla game, and the other two are from the expansions Corkscrew Follies and Loopy Landscapes, so if you're a completionist; you'll be sinking many, many hours into it!Other than that, the game has aged very well since when it was released back in 1999. So do you like managing parks, creating rollercoasters, completing scenario's to progress and having countless of hours of fun? Then throw your money at the screen and buy this game already!I give this game a definite 9/10, truly a wonderous game!

Posted: March 19
												 you're looking for a game review you've come to the wrong place. But if youre looking for a fantastic ravioli recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients- To Make the Dough375 grams (3 cups) plain flour1/2 teaspoon salt2 eggs1/4 cup (50 ml / 3½ tablespoons) olive oil1/2 cup (120 ml / 8 tablespoons) waterExtra flour for dusting - To Make Cheese Filling15 ounces (425 grams) container Ricotta cheese5 ounces (142 g/about 1/2 cup plus 2 tablespoons) "3 Cheese Italian Blend" (Parmesan, Romano & Asiago)Note: grate these cheeses yourself and create your own custom blend.1/2 cup cheddar cheese2 eggs, lightly beaten1/2 teaspoon salt1/2 teaspoon pepper- ExtrasYour favorite sauce for the ravioli (i.e. marinara/ marijuana)Parmesan cheeseBasilFried vegetablesShrimpFish slicesChicken pieces Make the Ravioli filling.- In a small mixing bowl, add the ricotta and mash with a fork.- Add in the 3-cheese blend, Cheddar cheese, eggs, salt, and pepper.- Mix all ingredients thoroughly until you have a smooth, paste-like consistency.- Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and place it in the refrigerator for about 30 minutes. Make the Ravioli dough.- Crack eggs into a large mixing bowl and beat them with a fork. Add water, oil, and salt. Mix.- Add 1 cup flour to the bowl. Use a fork to mix the flour with the eggs, water, oil, and salt. Repeat with the rest of the flour. Mix until a smooth dough is formed.- Clear and clean off a large work surface and dust it with flour. This is where you are going to roll out your dough.- Take the dough out of the mixing bowl, shape it into a ball, and place it on your work surface. Knead for at least 10 minutes or until it becomes elastic.- Dust a rolling pin with flour to prevent the dough from sticking. Roll out the dough until it is about 1/8 inch (1/3 cm) thick, or about the thickness of 2 stacked quarters.- With a cookie cutter or upside-down water glass, cut out circles in the dough (will make about 15-20 dough circles).- Ball up the unused dough and either roll it out and make a couple more raviolis, or wrap it and put in the freezer for another time. Dough can keep for weeks when frozen. Just make sure to wrap well so that it doesn’t suffer from freezer burn or absorb freezer odor. Fill the Ravioli shells.- Take the ravioli filling out of the refrigerator and place a tablespoon of it in middle of a dough.- Fill a small bowl with water, dip your fingers in, and moisten around the outer edge of the dough circle.- Fold the dough in half over the filling, making a half-moon shape. Be sure all the filling stays inside. Pinch the edges together and then seal the edges of the ravioli with a fork. Make sure to press firmly and go all the way around. This will add a “homemade” touch as well.- Repeat this process for all your dough circles.- Dust the finished ravioli with flour to keep them from sticking together. Form the Shells and Fill Using a Ravioli maker.- Roll the dough into two sheets- Place one sheet on the ravioli maker, and form the filling cups.- Fill with the ravioli mixture.- Lay the second sheet of dough on top, and roll it out. This will seal in the filling.- Remove and separate the finished raviolis.Cook the Ravioli.- Fill a large pot with water and bring to a boil.- Place the ravioli in boiling water for 5-6 minutes, or until they float. You can also test for doneness by nibbling on the edges to test.- If you don't want to make all the ravioli at one time, you can freeze the rest - Take ravioli out of boiling water with large slotted spoon and place on warmed platesServe it up.Top with your favorite sauce, grate some fresh cheese over it, and enjoy!

content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
												"The first installment of the RollerCoaster Tycoon franchise is a true example of an instant classic."A genre I play and like a lot are the simulation games: the SimCity series, Theme Park and Transport Tycoon Deluxe are good examples of the early games in this genre. Transport Tycoon was Chris Sawyer's first simulation game created in 1994 and obsessed by roller coasters, he created RollerCoaster Tycoon. And still after more than 20 years this game is great and for me the best in the series.The goal of the game is simple: built an amusement park including the biggest, fastest and baddest roller coasters you have ever seen. This goal repeats itself 21 times, but the different surroundings and kinds of rides and roller coasters make it a very addictive game. Each scenario, you start with a budget and a loan for building the first rides of your theme park to attract people. You can give each ride a name, price and different colours which is fun to do. When building a ride you can choose from a few standard designs, but building and designing a custom design is the way for having a real challenge.Besides placing rides, you have to have personnel to watch over your theme park. You will need handymen, mechanics, security guards and entertainers for every issue that may occur with the hundreds of sloppy visitors. They vomit, throw garbage, demolish the rides and scenery and are not happy. Well, not always. You can hire enough personnel placing them in your park and they will walk just around or you can hire less personnel and then assign a route to them. The last option has the advantage that for example the mechanics are on time to inspect and/or repair a ride, but it takes more time planning the routes. It is up to you.As I am not a roller coaster fanatic and therefore do not know all the sorts and names of the turns and stuff, building one is so much fun. How good your coaster is going to be, depends on the amount of money you have to spend. That is an easy rule, but there 3 ratings that can make or kill your coaster. These are the nausea, excitement and intensity rating. A good score on all three, extreme not included, will attract lots of visitors. And a good score on these ratings will cost you. Building above and undergrounds is possible. Building undergrounds is pretty difficult, because it is sometimes hard to see where your entrance path or coaster is.The graphics and sound are great. The lovely tiny people walking around, the rides and coasters you see are detailed and colourful. Menus are easy to use: the different sorts of rides and the flora and fauna are categorized into tabs.Overall it is a true fun and very addictive game.Ratings:Graphics: 8/10Sound: 8/10Gameplay: 8,5/10

number of helpful: 10 of 10 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												I cannot tell you how happy I am that Steam doesn't show you the amount of hours I have spent on this game as a kid, and I am somewhat glad. I had this game waaaay back when it first came out, on my Windows DOS machine. This was the game of my childhood, and I couldn't tell you how happy I was when I discovered that it had been released to work on newer generation computers. Anyway, this game is great if you like to build, and then run the show. It's a pixel game, so it's similar to the likes of theme hospital, or any of these "tycoon" themed games. The aim is to create a thriving theme park, and keep your guests happy. Pretty much everything is customisable, and you can also create your own roller-coasters, which I had hours and hours and hours of fun with as a kid. I was also really impressed with the "Real Life Parks" option when creating a new game. I chose Alton Towers, and was surprised to see a very impressive recreation of the famous UK park - someone, somewhere, has a lot of spare time!This game is great for people who like to create and innovate. It's a fun, bright, colourful & an interesting game, and rest assured you'll be following my footsteps and playing this for hours and hours after you've bought it. This game never really goes out of date, because every game you play is different!

												RollerCoaster Tycoon 1, a game we waited 6 years after RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 Platinum came out in 2008. This is my favourite PC game since i always played this game when i was a kid and with my sister. RollerCoaster Tycoon 1 had to bring most peoples childhood which is why this game is 1 reason to love. You just bought a plot of land or a park with rides already in it, its your job to making enough profit, get enough people (its not easy guys) and.... watch people die (your messed up if you choose to do that. The game is mostly about patient if you dont have any, than your kinda screwed. If you choose to ignore the objective than have fun playing an endless game even if you beat the park level. Your guests are kinda messed up since they literally puke on the ground. You need janitors, mechanics, security guards to make your park safe and get awards which increase your chance to get more people.I give this game 10 out of 10 since there is nothing wrong with this game and since this is a deluxe version, they fixed some bugs from the 1st version. content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
												In the 1 and a half days of owning this game, I spent over 10 hours in it.Send help.PLEASE.EDIT:Since this has actually gotten a surprising amount of attention, I'll actually write a proper review.RTC is an isometric management game made by the ever so wonderful Chris Sawyer, who is an absolute genius when it comes to these types of games. The focus of this game would be the missions, which usually requires you to have at least a certain number of guests, and at least a certain park approval rating.On the first couple missions, there's hardly anything pre-built, or in your way, so you can just keep playing those on a loop, or continue them after you win to build the park of your dreams. Some of the later missions have a lake or something in your way, or maybe a park with rides in it already. It adds nice challenge, but I prefer the empty ones.If you like management games, this is a must have for your Steam library! If not, but you're curious, I recommend watching a couple videos on it, plus with the refunds now there's hardly any risk.

Posted: December 20, 2015
												A now dated game, RollerCoaster Tycoon: Deluxe is a theme park building sim. At its time it was facinating watching each customer walk through your parks gates and onto the first ride you built. Designing that first coaster and having it explode randomly a week later.  When little Jimmy (Guest 3785) gets lost because you forgot to finsih the pathway. Ahhh yes reminds me of drinking that 48 pack of Arizona Iced Tea from Sams Club I asked for Christmas one year which ruined my teeth.. the good old days we called it.This was one of my first PC games when I was a young man. I would get home from school and boot it up, hearing those same rollercoaster tracks on the title screen over and over. I never did get to the last few parks you could unlock but I have always wanted to so I bought it as soon as I saw it on steam.A must buy for those who love old sim games.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												The best classic game ever!More realistic than you might think:-Attractions break down (and might even crash)-Reliability and popularity decreases over time-Guests won't ride too intense coasters-View the cash spend and remaining of every single guest-Start with noting, take a loan and make profit-Set ride fees according to ride popularity and entry fee-A lot of choices: free attractions/high park entry fee or free entry/expensive rides (or ask money for both ofcourse, which is not possible in RCT2)-Small trains lose speed faster than long trains, and rollercoasters are faster with guests riding on it-Advertising your park brings a lot a new visitors-Cheaper coaster types attract less guests-Choose what you want to research-Design your coasters correctly to make it worth every single cent-Understand your guests, and become the ultimate rollercoaster tycoon! A must have for any strategy fan!(is there any way to add the hundreds hours played on the cd-version to my play time?)

Posted: June 19, 2016
												Mr Bones wild ride never ends... This game is really what you make of it. You can play it seriously, aiming for the objectives; but you can also have fun making epic rollercoasters and other rides, and killing sims with doomsday devices as well as getting them lost in endless mazes. Or you can theme an amazing looking park where everything works perfectly together.Objectively speaking, the isometric view has its ups and (mostly) downs, and the AI is just horrible. There's a LOT of waiting around if you're a good player. To us older fans, it's part of the charm, but I guess newer players can't be expected to be so enthusiastic.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												Roller coasters are life. RCT makes me so very happy; this game was a childhood classic for me and I still go back to it every time. I remember the first time a roller coaster exploded in front of my eyes (Diamond Heights pre-built coaster BS), it was magical and 16 people died.First of all the price is currently ridiculous for what you get. Only $6.49 CA DAMN! Even when it was first released it didn't cost nearly as much as one would expect after having played the game.To play the main parks it takes approx 50 hrs (give or take), this doesn't include the other 2 WHOLE EXPANSIONS that it comes with, each of which appear to take just as long AND the other 5 additional bonus parks ontop of that (3 of which are modeled off real-world parks). I don't think anyone could ask or even think to ask for better value.So happy I might actually die :)The only downside is that its not usually very challenging once you get the basics down (Rainbow Valley insanity being my main exception to this). I mean, yeah, every now and then it throws you for a loop by causing a coaster (or one time a water slide WTF?) to explode 2 months before your objective is due; but after the first couple of parks you should know how to deal with inspection times, mechanic requirements, accessibility, and PR making this a rare and manageable occasion. I remain hopeful that the expansions will add some pizazz to the game play (as I have never had the chance to play the explansions until now) but even if it does not, the game itself is just so satisfying when you achieve your goals and all your little people clap for you and release their balloons that they bought with their own little money into the air in celebration of your momentous achievement!

content:
Posted: March 20
												I bought Roller Coaster Tycoon relatively new in 1999 and I don’t really recall what put me in such a rush to buy it. Did I play a demo? Read a review? Was I excited about an upcoming trip to Six Flags Great America? Some combination of the 3? The answer to that is lost with time.I wasn’t the lite-sim veteran and seeker I am today, I enjoyed Aerobiz Supersonic and the Sim City series but beyond that I hadn’t really dabbled in the genre. I’m not sure I ever played a game with such low stakes to that point. Half-Life starts with your research team breaking reality and charges you with fighting through both otherworldly creatures and a deadly serious black-ops regiment. Chrono Trigger had you traveling and attempting to save time itself. Even in Super Mario Bros. you’re chasing and fighting a large fire-breathing bipedal turtle who kidnapped a princess.In Roller Coaster Tycoon you build and manage an amusement park. Winning oft means providing people a good and affordable time and making some cash in the process. Losing means people don’t come to your park and the ones that do are let down; and you may end up in debt. Despite the low stakes, unspectacular-for-1997 graphics and the sometimes restrictive scenario structure this game is a shining jewel, a beacon to us video game fans – showing us what gaming can be.  It’s far more intuitive and engrossing than Bullfrog’s respectable Theme Park, even with added options and more freedom there’s rarely ever a reason to feel lost or stuck. Those low-res textures which are only a slight step up from Chris Sawyer’s previous gem, 1994’s Transport Tycoon, really play beautifully with each other. Rides, coasters and peeps move around in a brisk yet non-chaotic manner.Ah, those peeps – the lifeblood of the game – they look like they’re made from around 3 pixels and have less visual character than those Amiga-era Sensible World of Soccer players they share a passing resemblance to. These diminutive and faceless little blobs of color are very effectively animated and presented – green faces leading to vomit, the happy hop after a sweet ride, the quickness in their decisions to go or not go on a ride. It’s hard to to love the little guys and I can’t see why so many people enjoy ending their tiny digital lives.Later RCTs still have the effective and rewarding gameplay loop and fantastically open coaster creation and maybe even add a few more bells and whistles than the inaugural title has to offer. They never seem to add up to so much more than the sum of their parts the way RCT1 did. The sheer elegance of the base game’s level design is never reached on any other core RCT.This game is not only valuable for it’s history and influence on game design, production and marketing, it’s still danged fun to play.  It’s a must-own, must-play and is and will likely continue to remain one of the finest games ever made.

content:
Posted: January 13
												This product has a really good value!I can't belive that my Windows 10 likes this as much as I do. This classic of the classics had no argument with my system and I can announce that I am hooked into it again. Roller Coaster Tycoon is like a theme park version of Sim City or Cities: Skylines and the thing which keeps me getting back to it over and over again is complicated but yet relatively simple design and controls, with which you design, create and manage your park. There is dozens of different maps and challenges to play and the key feature is that every playtrough is more or less different than the last because you get exact freedom to plan the overall layout and architecture and create Roller Coasters from tiny joy rides to most extreme coasters beyond this world (if you can afford it). The another cool thing is that the parks can be decorated by creating some beautiful sceneries to make your park even better experience for your customers. The management is the thing that assures that player won't feel bored at anytime - if there is not anything to build you can check that do quests have something to complain about: rides will get broken, streets need more handymen to clean up some vomits next to roller coaster ride's exit, some ride has gotten old and thus over priced etc. You also must take care that visitors have always something to eat or drink close-by.All these and various other tasks must be handled well enough to pass the maps and unlock some new ones. While all this may sound hard it is not, thanks to the ultimately successful user interface, which lets you solve things by few clicks without getting lost in hell of management windows. In my opinion this is the very feature that makes RCT1 and RCT2 better then the third installment.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												Oh man, here we go. Before I start my review of this game, I would just like to say that I have been a fan of the RollerCoaster Tycoon series ever since I started playing it when I was five years old, and the first game will always be in my memory. Alright, lets get this review on the roll.Ever wondered what it would be like to run your very own amusement park, to build rides at the click of a button, and such, then RollerCoaster Tycoon is definetly for you! RollerCoaster Tycoon is one of the best PC games of all time, and it deserves it's place in history as it. The story as to how RollerCoaster Tycoon began was when Scottish video game developer Chris Sawyer, who developed the legendary Transport Tycoon, was planning on making a sequel to the previously mentioned game, but when in the process of making it, Sawyer developed a keen interest in rollercoasters, and with that being done, he shifted his focus from that to making RollerCoaster Tycoon, and thus, a masterpiece was born.The basic gameplay of RollerCoaster Tycoon is simple. You're tasked with a specific park of your choosing, and your job there is to reach the goal that is given to you at hand without completely destroying the reputation of the park itself. This can either mean to achieve a certain park rating, amount of guests, and other such tasks that can keep you busy for a while, and with that being said and done, it's time to start building!You mainly play from a thirdperson view of the park itself, and you can build whatever you want in it, as long as you have sufficient funds. The game has a variety of different attractions to build, ranging from the gently ferris wheel, to the pulse-pounding steel roller coaster. Doing all this is very fun and addicting and can keep you occupied for a very long time. Since this is also deluxe, you'll have some extra fun with additional scenarios to play in, so you can be sure to have endless hours of gameplay. As the "Tycoon" that you are, building all these rollercoasters, rides, stalls, scenery, and paying all your staff in the park is costly, you'll need to be more careful with what you spend your money on, or else you'll need to start taking loans out, and that's never a good thing. With all being said and done, RollerCoaster Tycoon is one of the best games of this generation, and a must have for everyone of all ages.In conclusion, RollerCoaster Tycoon is definitely a must own, and is a materpiece that could never be remade.

Posted: December 30, 2016
												First time i loaded up this game in years and a wave of nostaliga hit me full in the face, i almost wept in happiness after so long!This is one of those true classic games that you can't replace, sure there have been sequels but none of them can stand on a hand or a foot to the original. Simply put this game is a product of an era where some of the best games were ever made, in the late 90's to early 00's.the graphics are not great by todays standards, but who really cares? the game is fantastic to play.You are an aspiring mogul looking to make a name for yourselves in the country by building the best, more profitable and greatest theme park around, to get you started, you get a few gentle, thrill and extreme rides along with food stalls and toilets. with the tools at your command, you go out to build that dream.It's simplistic and that works for me as far too many games these days are too complicated or have too much flash and not enough substance. this game fits all the boxes needing a tick for a tycoon game.

Rank: 7/10Recommendation(s): Don’t expect to play a classic on new systems. Play RCT2 instead.Major Theme: For the real hardcore old school gamers.Bought at Price: $1.62 (Steam Sale)I might still have the real CDs for this game (yes CDs… Not DVDs). Rollercoaster Tycoon 1 and 2 were my go to games before I joined Steam.I remember spending a lot more time on RCT2 than the first, but there are still some memorable parks in RTC1 that I still like to visit.If you are new to the older Rollercoaster Tycoon games, pick up RCT2 (and OpenRCT2 if you are using Win 10/8). You will have a lot more to play around with, RCT1 is really just for those who had it part of their childhood.The graphics are simple, the gameplay is simple. Nothing more really needs to be said about this game.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												I have very fond memories of playing this game when I was a child. Easy to learn, but with a lot of room for improvement especially with the development of bigger and better rollercoasters (learning what works with what type of coasters). All-around a very fun game with one shortfall: a lack of different challenges for the various parks. Most of the time it's just have this many people in your park by the end of year (insert year) and a park rating of (insert park rating). However, don't let this deter you from purchasing this game. With the deluxe edition, there is at least 300+ hours of fun to be had at a low, low price. My score: 9/10. You won't be disappointed once you get the hang of it.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Are you a nostalgic fheg? Then this game is for you. Re-live your days with those impressive for the time graphics and that ever so annoyingly catchy theme song. Enjoy mopping up puke and making go-kart rides that are so long people complain to get off. Complete with vomit splatters and panda costumed entertainers, this game will bring back all the good memories of what it was like to be anti-socially locked in your room while clicking away at your computer while you launch coaster riders to death into enemy parks for the sake of ratings. (Seriously who thought our childhood nightmares of rollercoasters bolting off the tracks and plummeting into a fiery death lived out would be a good idea?) Build your own coasters, complete scenarios, and plant dem flowers. Charge 5 dollars for the bathroom and laugh as people complain. Take a tip from the Sims, drown your guests in water. (WHY U NO SWIM!) Build your dream rollercoaster to only be ignored by your guests like a red-headed step-child. This game is a charming play, this isn't a re-mastered version, it's the old school stuff, so if you're looking for a newer RollerCoaster Tycoon look elsewhere. But seriously, this game is a gem, must git. 10/10

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21
												The parts of RCT that have aged poorly:-- The visuals-- The audio quality-- The UI and menus-- The animations (which were gorgeous for their time btw)-- Just about everything that has to do with how the game looks.The parts of RCT that have aged extremely well:-- Building roller coasters is still a blast, with simple controls and lots of trial and error that legitimately pays off.-- The management part of the game is still brilliant and engrossing.-- The variety of maps and scenarios means hours of content.-- Plenty of options for personalising your park.-- Picking up customers who complain and dropping them in the water to drown them, or making them go on an unfinished or otherwise dangerous ride so they crash to their death, is still morbidly satisfying.-- Just about everything that has to do with how the game feels.In short, an immense amount of nostalgia and happy memories of playing RCT is what led me to buying and playing this in 2016. The fact that the game is still a ton of fun is what led me to play it for more than 100 happy hours in 2016. This is one of the best simulation/management games ever made, and THE definitive amusement park game, and it's a testament to its greatness that unlike many dinosaurs of turn-of-the-century PC gaming, it's still great today.

												When I was younger, I played this game non-stop and it was one of my favorites of all time. Having gotten older and gone back to this, I can see how it becomes repetitive, with a set amount of rides in the whole game. number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												This game is a whole lot of wonderful nostolgia.  I would sink endless hours into this game as a kid, and as computers got newer getting the thing to work was harder and harder. Then steam came out with this! Completely worth the 6 bucks! And it even has the 2 expansion packs to boot! This game is old, so bear in mind it's isometic rather than 3D so if you are used to a free-form camera you may need a moment to adjust to having it locked at 90 degree angles. However, I never found myself struggling to place objects because of the camera. The AI is.... not the best.  Your park layout has to be, for the most part, a strait line or a large circle.  Otherwise your park guests get lost. However, I don't find this takes away from the game. Placing information kiosks and using monorails or chairlifts help with this "guest 102 is lost and can't find the park exit" nonsense.A great feature is any alert it gives you, good or bad, you can bring the camera to that spot. Lost guest? pick him up and show him the park exit.  Despite it's age the coaster design part of the game is still my favorite.  A good variety of coasters, options, designs, I can truly build the monster coasts of my dreams. And make incomplete ones that rocket guests to their dooms like a total sadist.  If you were a fan of the game a a kid, totally dive back in it's a wonderful game.  And to anyone curious about trying it for the first time, it's an excellent simulation game and you really can let your creativity shine.  ONLY issue I ever encountered: The game will strobe if you have the program F.lux running. This is a program to dim your monitor to yellow-toned colors at night to reduce eye strain.  But it's incompatible with this game. All you need to do is disable F.lux before firing up the game and you will have zero issues.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												For me, a person who has play this back during it's early release, this game does not lose its fun easily. The scenarios may be very easy for awhile, but overall it is very fun and enjoyable, and a good learning experience for those who like to build their own rides within the game! Anyway, let's get to the breakdown for it.Gameplay: 7.5/10This game holds a simple but fun hold of its gameplay. To keep it short and simple, it takes the standard overview "god" role to building things, and allows you to monitor everything and do as you will. While it is a relatively common style, it fits well.Sound: 8/10The roller-coasters available in this game for the most part have very good sounds built around them, as is the music of the rides you can choose. However, the smaller rides (minus the Haunted house and rides without a cart and/or moving vehicle) like the Ferris wheel and the Merry-Go-Round have no sound around them if the music is turned off. Whether it was intentional or not, it's not really that big of the deal, the sound still is very good.Graphics: 9/10For its time, the graphics were built very high-end, especially the rides. The detail put around the scenery and the texture of the land is pretty amazing for its original release, but the people seem to have been left out of this small loop, like they have gotten just a tad bit lazy. It's not really that bad though, and is truly a great sight for its age!Controls: 6/10The controls consist of a simple click-and-go kinda game. For the most part that is it, but you can hot-key many things, like closing windows, screenshots, opening the tabs available and even for seeing through the ground. The hot-keying is almost a necessity for those looking to do things very quickly, as the clicking can be very burdensome when doing many things you are trying to do. The hot-keys save it, though.Overall: 7.6/10 (Pretty Good)This game certainly holds its head up high for those who look into tycoon games from many angles. A few things here and there can get a little bothering, but overall it's a solid slate, and I would recommend it for anyone willing to try it out!

												I remember playing this with my mom as a kid and I could never get past some of the harder scenarios. Now that I've come back to it I've been having a lot of fun getting to all of the parks I could only dream of unlocking. I lost my original disk, so when I saw that it was on steam for such a low price I bought it immediately.There's only a few problems, most of them technical.1) steam overlay and screenshots don't work, plus I have no idea where to find the built-in screenshots folder2) once you leave the game or alt-tab out, opening/minimizing/closing windows becomes weird, and the only fix I've found is to restart the computer3) there isn't a real sandbox mode. RCT2/3 are the better sandbox games, so take a look at those insteadDespite all of this though, I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone who loves building or simulation games.

												Played this game nonstop like 7 years ago, you could say I "grew up on this game" so my opinion is may be slightlly biased in favor of this game compared to somone who just got this a few weeks ago. Nevertheless, it's addicting and very fun, an easy way to waste hours. You run a theme park and can make a ton of rollercoasters, stand/shops, trains, farris wheels and other stuff, you can every create you own roller coaster from scratch just make sure you park go'ers enjoy it as in it doesnt make them too nausious or have the que line too long that they get tired of waiting. Very fun, especially for when it came out,. Graphics were good for the time it was released but now have a limited screen resolution rate. Don't be suprised when only half your screen is filled when you play this if your playing in 1920x1080, and this is when it is "fullscreen" which is the only option, there is no windowed view but really how many people actually use that. Good game, easy to put 100 hours into this game within a month.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
												This game is a nice upgrade from the original. My significant other purchased this for me and I was pleasantly surprised with upgrades, new maps, and buildings the original did not offer for a vanilla purchase. I love this game just as much as I did when I was younger. If you are looking for a pleasant, sandbox tycoon game, with a little spice of being able to create some amazing rollercoasters, this is definitely one to try.As for gameplay, It changes up what you have to work with with every map when it comes to terrain. Each with their own difficulty, and you don't have to play every map to unlock new ones. They offer at least five in the beginning for variety at the start. unfortunately, the rides don't vary much from map to map. It may get repetitive for some. What rides you get at the BEGINNING vary from map to map, but you will get your simple rides always first. Building a rollercoaster that people cannot get enough of is a great feeling. It is a rather rewarding game and, if you don't want to complete the objectives, you can cause a little mischief by seeing just how far you can make rollercoasters launch off their tracks and into the air.The only bad note I have is that it runs rather weird with my computer, since it is such an old game. Some text boxes don't show up, but you can still type in them, so it is not a huge problem. Maybe it will be fixed in the future.Final note: This game is a wonderful romp as any tycoon game should be.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												Without doubt, this is one of tbest tycoon games I have ever played.I first played this game when it was released back in 2000 and recently discovered it on Steam and fell in love with it again.The game is basically management of a theme park, which you build, either from scratch or from a starting point, depending on the scenario.  You add rides, rollercoasters, eateries, facilities, etc.  You must recruit handymen (absolutely vital as the park guests hate the site of sick on the ground!), engineers (your rides will breakdown regularly) & security guards (vandals exist you know).The best aspect though, is the designing of your rides.  Some are set, such as the Merry Go Round, but others, such as all the rollercoasters, the log flume etc, you can either accept pre set designs or have a go yourself.  Piece by piece.  There is no better reward than the self design of a monster rollercoaster that the crowds love.I use Windows 8.2 and this game runs smoothly.Buy this game.

Posted: January 23, 2015
												I am one of the few players to have owned Roller Coaster Tycoon since March 31st, 1999. This game IS my childhood, it wasnt a part of it, but it was my life as a child.RCT has taken a huge chunk of my life away, as I have spent thousands of hours creating parks, creating scenarios and editing custom content. And im here to tell you after nearly 16 years of gameplay, why you should buy and cherish this relic.The objective is simple. Build the theme park of your dreams. But it goes much deeper then it seems. There's staff to manage, bills to pay, capital to gain, advertisements to be used, and new rides to be build. RCT is simply not a reskin of Theme Park, it's a buisness simulator underneath a Theme Park simulator. It's extremely open ended and there is no TRUE endgame, other then beating all the parks. It is litterally endless thanks to the support of custom content and scenarios that are always popping up through the internet.Many people have complained about the steam port lacking compatibility with Windows 7/8. I have yet to run into any serious issues with the port. The only thing that HAS YET to work is the Steam Overlay, but it's to be expected.In all, Buy the game. Play it, introduce your children to it. Enjoy it.

Posted: December 27, 2014
												This is pure nostalgia for me.  I had this game years ago and loved it, but never did complete all the scenarios.  Saw it was out and on sale and jumped at the chance to grab it and finally complete them all. The graphics are a bit dated, and there are many more features in the later versions of the game.  But this is the one that started it all and I'm having a great time!  If you played this back in the day, you'll likely enjoy having it available in Steam.  And if you didn't play it back in the day, you might still enjoy it now.I especially like griefing the guests by drowning ones that had a particularly bad attitude.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												Don't let an abysmal final entry draw you away from the series.  RCT1 is as good a game as it always has been, and I daresay it's one of the greatest ever made.  When Steam offered the nomination for the "Test of Time" award, I thought very briefly of X-COM... then ignored that thought and went straight here.  Then I took that award back, so I could give it to the game again.==Made by a single person, and with NO ENGINE (the entire game is written in Assembly), Chris Sawyer's Rollercoaster Tycoon 1 and 2 fall under the definition of a masterpiece.  They play well, run smoothly, and have all sorts of great features that other tgames wouldn't catch up to for years.  When SimCity 2000 and 3000, and even 4 were simply running cities with fake-people sprites occasionally walking around, RCT had something only Bullfrog had succeeded in-- a management game with AGENTS.  Every single one of the people in your park are active.  When they're idle and bored, they find something else to do, and the guest count can reach well beyond even 1000 guests.  They're never inactive, the performance never tanks; it pulls off the simulation of thousands flawlessly.  IN 1998!What makes this game stand out so much from older titles, however, is the clean interface and visuals.  The isometric graphics still hold up rather well.  The performance is at a stable framerate constantly, and while I'm not sure where this cap sits, it's at least 40 FPS and never drops.  The interface is neatly organized, and every time you click a menu, it IMMEDIATELY pulls up that menu with an accompanying sound.  It also behaves like Windows, with windows appearing per menu that can be dragged around the screen freely.  It actually LOOKS like a game instead of an alien interface, something that can't be said about other classics like X-COM and Theme Hospital.Perhaps what draws me to the game the most, however, is how you're genuinely building a world in it.  It doesn't have much in terms of background music, and at first, the park feels empty; however, you start placing your rides, give them selective background music, and extend your park.  This music adds up to build an atmosphere.  Then, your new guests will make noise.  You'll hear the clanging of capitalism and greed every time a customer buys something, and your guests are louder depending on how many there are.  Coasters going downhill with passengers will have them scream.  You'll also see them very well-animated-- they'll walk around, they'll pull out umbrellas if they bought one for $20 at one of our kiosks... heh heh, they'll throw up if they get sick.  Yeah, their 'tasks?'  All based on their own selfish desires.  They'll want to be happy, need to be awake, need to use the bathroom, and can't take motion sickness.  Their actions all change based on these stats, and it's in your best interest to accompany them all.In reality, I'm making the game sound more complex than it is to play.  These mechanics are slowly introduced to you, and I played this at a very young age without a tutorial; it just doesn't suffer from the usual complexity problems of these old games.  If you need it, there's a tutorial that consists of watching someone play in real time, essentially a demo of Chris Sawyer taking over the mouse and playing for you.  You can hit Escape to take control at any time, but assuming you don't you'll get to see where all the options you need are.  In reality, however, the game won't take too long to figure out for the most part.As far as replayability value goes, you just shouldn't be concerned.  There's several challenges to go around, playing with the game rules in various ways by giving you a task and either a piece of land to build on or a prebuilt park in its early stages to improve.  You will NOT run out of content-- in all my years of playing this game, I still have yet to clear through all the scenarios, and Forest Frontiers will always be a special memory to me.====================BUY THIS GAME.  It hasn't aged at all.  It's still better than any modern sim... SimCity 5, Cities Skylines, and Planet Coaster all fall short in some areas that this game nails, despite all being good games themselves.  Its compatibility is near-perfect (and if by some odd chance you run into an issue, there's a lengthy guide detailing workarounds and solutions), and a hexeditor widescreen hack is out there if you need it.If I don't end the review here, I would ramble endlessly about all the things this game does right, but as it stands the best way to do that is to experience it yourself.  The Steam release is a simple port, true, but nonetheless the game looks and runs perfectly.  It still is a highly innovative and organized game, and few things stand in the way of showing off its strengths.  Pick it up, for your own good, and try it yourself; whether it's the full track editor allowing you to build custom rides and coasters, the atmosphere-building sound design and gameplay design decisions that help it feel like a living world, the management of your finances and distribution of staff to keep the park at max efficiency, or the morbid prospect of drowning panda-costumed staff and throwing coasters into the lake, or perhaps any combination of the two, this is a game you simply must play.

Posted: September 16, 2016
												Important note: If you have problems loading this game, consider installing OpenRCT2.  Not only can it help you run this game (and Rollercoaster Tycoon 2), it adds many features that did not exist in the original.This game was very fun when it first came out, and it is still fun now.  Before Rollercoaster Tycoon, the best (only?) theme park sim was Theme Park.  That game was decent, but Rollercoaster Tycoon was a huge step forward in the genre.  The game has aged very well, and still holds up today.  Whether you want to build the most elaborate coasters, build the biggest parks, or just want to drown your customers or immolate them with a coaster destined to crash in a fiery explosing, grab this game if you do not already own it.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												RollerCoaster Tycoon was one of my favorite games growing up as many people can relate and though much time has passed since I intially started playing I have to admit that the appeal has not lowered since then! Sure, the graphics are extremely simple but that is to be expected for a game of its age. Plus it does not feel terribly dated since the artwork is somewhat stylized. The only other potential downside I can see is that the gameplay can seem rather repeditive but that is to be expected from a game based on a singular purpose. Still, the number of challenge parks and the variety what you can do certainly makes up fofr this. Still love RollerCoaster Tycoon and am glad it has been added to the Steam store!

Posted: November 29, 2016
												I played this when I was 7, and it's still very good. Enough said.In all seriousness, nostalgia does cloud our perception, and I don't play a lot of simulation games, so I may not be the best person to review this game since I don't have much to compare it to. I haven't played more than a few minutes of the sequels and games by other companies inspired by the series like Planet Coaster. Those are probably a better option if you're looking for a modern experience, as this game definitely is a bit dated. Still, for its age, I don't feel that the UI is too clunky or the learning curve is too steep. Fun to pick up for a couple hours exactly once, or to dump days into, if you have that kind of time.I never did fully understand a lot of the roller coaster-specific mechanics, like intensity and excitement, which can be limiting when I'm trying to make a park the best it can be. The track builder is a bit clunky, too. Still, I'm a lot better at the budgeting and management aspects than I was when I was a kid, and the game can still be easy or challenging depending on the scenario. The quirks and flaws are a drop in the bucket of nostalgic goodness. Or lake. Lake of goodness, which your guests can fall into and drown.

												Important note: If you have problems loading this game, consider installing OpenRCT2.  Not only can it help you run this game (and Rollercoaster Tycoon 2), it adds many features that did not exist in the original.This game was very fun when it first came out, and it is still fun now.  Before Rollercoaster Tycoon, the best (only?) theme park sim was Theme Park.  That game was decent, but Rollercoaster Tycoon was a huge step forward in the genre.  The game has aged very well, and still holds up today.  Whether you want to build the most elaborate coasters, build the biggest parks, or just want to drown your customers or immolate them with a coaster destined to crash in a fiery explosing, grab this game if you do not already own it.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												RollerCoaster Tycoon was one of my favorite games growing up as many people can relate and though much time has passed since I intially started playing I have to admit that the appeal has not lowered since then! Sure, the graphics are extremely simple but that is to be expected for a game of its age. Plus it does not feel terribly dated since the artwork is somewhat stylized. The only other potential downside I can see is that the gameplay can seem rather repeditive but that is to be expected from a game based on a singular purpose. Still, the number of challenge parks and the variety what you can do certainly makes up fofr this. Still love RollerCoaster Tycoon and am glad it has been added to the Steam store!
