Posted: November 23, 2016
												Don't let an abysmal final entry draw you away from the series.  RCT1 is as good a game as it always has been, and I daresay it's one of the greatest ever made.  When Steam offered the nomination for the "Test of Time" award, I thought very briefly of X-COM... then ignored that thought and went straight here.  Then I took that award back, so I could give it to the game again.==Made by a single person, and with NO ENGINE (the entire game is written in Assembly), Chris Sawyer's Rollercoaster Tycoon 1 and 2 fall under the definition of a masterpiece.  They play well, run smoothly, and have all sorts of great features that other tgames wouldn't catch up to for years.  When SimCity 2000 and 3000, and even 4 were simply running cities with fake-people sprites occasionally walking around, RCT had something only Bullfrog had succeeded in-- a management game with AGENTS.  Every single one of the people in your park are active.  When they're idle and bored, they find something else to do, and the guest count can reach well beyond even 1000 guests.  They're never inactive, the performance never tanks; it pulls off the simulation of thousands flawlessly.  IN 1998!What makes this game stand out so much from older titles, however, is the clean interface and visuals.  The isometric graphics still hold up rather well.  The performance is at a stable framerate constantly, and while I'm not sure where this cap sits, it's at least 40 FPS and never drops.  The interface is neatly organized, and every time you click a menu, it IMMEDIATELY pulls up that menu with an accompanying sound.  It also behaves like Windows, with windows appearing per menu that can be dragged around the screen freely.  It actually LOOKS like a game instead of an alien interface, something that can't be said about other classics like X-COM and Theme Hospital.Perhaps what draws me to the game the most, however, is how you're genuinely building a world in it.  It doesn't have much in terms of background music, and at first, the park feels empty; however, you start placing your rides, give them selective background music, and extend your park.  This music adds up to build an atmosphere.  Then, your new guests will make noise.  You'll hear the clanging of capitalism and greed every time a customer buys something, and your guests are louder depending on how many there are.  Coasters going downhill with passengers will have them scream.  You'll also see them very well-animated-- they'll walk around, they'll pull out umbrellas if they bought one for $20 at one of our kiosks... heh heh, they'll throw up if they get sick.  Yeah, their 'tasks?'  All based on their own selfish desires.  They'll want to be happy, need to be awake, need to use the bathroom, and can't take motion sickness.  Their actions all change based on these stats, and it's in your best interest to accompany them all.In reality, I'm making the game sound more complex than it is to play.  These mechanics are slowly introduced to you, and I played this at a very young age without a tutorial; it just doesn't suffer from the usual complexity problems of these old games.  If you need it, there's a tutorial that consists of watching someone play in real time, essentially a demo of Chris Sawyer taking over the mouse and playing for you.  You can hit Escape to take control at any time, but assuming you don't you'll get to see where all the options you need are.  In reality, however, the game won't take too long to figure out for the most part.As far as replayability value goes, you just shouldn't be concerned.  There's several challenges to go around, playing with the game rules in various ways by giving you a task and either a piece of land to build on or a prebuilt park in its early stages to improve.  You will NOT run out of content-- in all my years of playing this game, I still have yet to clear through all the scenarios, and Forest Frontiers will always be a special memory to me.====================BUY THIS GAME.  It hasn't aged at all.  It's still better than any modern sim... SimCity 5, Cities Skylines, and Planet Coaster all fall short in some areas that this game nails, despite all being good games themselves.  Its compatibility is near-perfect (and if by some odd chance you run into an issue, there's a lengthy guide detailing workarounds and solutions), and a hexeditor widescreen hack is out there if you need it.If I don't end the review here, I would ramble endlessly about all the things this game does right, but as it stands the best way to do that is to experience it yourself.  The Steam release is a simple port, true, but nonetheless the game looks and runs perfectly.  It still is a highly innovative and organized game, and few things stand in the way of showing off its strengths.  Pick it up, for your own good, and try it yourself; whether it's the full track editor allowing you to build custom rides and coasters, the atmosphere-building sound design and gameplay design decisions that help it feel like a living world, the management of your finances and distribution of staff to keep the park at max efficiency, or the morbid prospect of drowning panda-costumed staff and throwing coasters into the lake, or perhaps any combination of the two, this is a game you simply must play.

												This was one of the first games I ever played.I played every other entry in the series, but I never had as much fun as I had with the first one.Besides the obvious reasons for not liking the third installment (3D-ish and such) , some might say: What about the second game? It has everything from the first game + new rides and everything.Well that's somewhat the truth, but for me it wasn't enough new things to justify a new game instead of an addon. Also unlocking new parks in the first game was a nice goal and made the replay value higher if you failed a goal of a park, because you can another one if you manage it. :)Another big problem with the second game for me is that the new rides (especially in the addons) are just reskins of existing rides, so the number of real new rides isn't that high.Well if you like a nice theme park game than stick with this one, because you still have the goal for unlocking new parks and not just a semi-sandbox game like the 2nd.Ps: Please don't ask about the weird "World" game. xD

content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												The original Rollercoaster Tycoon is not only one of the most favourite games from my childhood, but it is one of my favourite and most loved games of all time.Rollercoaster Tycoon still holds up until this day.  The mechanics may seem a little clunky compared to back in 1999, but that should not pushh you away from buying this game. In Rollercoaster Tycoon you need to build a theme park to complete a set of objectives set out for you at the beginning of each scenario. Some of these objectives can be completed easily while others will take quite a bit of time.  There is many different theme parks and scenarios to chose from, as this version of Rollercoaster Tycoon also includes the expansions!  Pretty good for £4.79.There are many different attractions to unlock from Merry Go Round's to Viking Ship to huge Rollercoasters; which is done through researching.  The researching mechanic is really straightforward,  the player needs to select from a bunch of preset options from "minimum" to "maximum"  each option has a different cost attached to it.The game is not called Rollercoaster Tycoon for no reason!  The game enables the player to design and create their own custom rollercoaster from scratch!  Make every turn and drop of the track completely unique.  Watch that excitement rating! Players can also create rides such as log flumes, kart racing and even transport attractions such as a monorail.Of course, you need staff to run a theme park.  The player can recruit four different types of staff:  Handyman, Mechanic, Security and Entertainer.  The handyman is used to keep the staff tidy, water plants and mow the lawn,  the mechanic of course repairs any broken down rides while the security keeps those annoyances away meanwhile the entertainer is busy...well, entertaining people in many different cute and quirky costumes.The game offers quite a few customization options.  The player can set how fast a ride can go - Watch out, don't let it crash and kill your guests! Decorations such as statues, water features, plants and trees are available.  Fences, benches and trash cans are needed to keep guests happy! If you have fond memories of this game and are reading reviews to make sure it isn't just nostalgia making you interested in the purchase - I found say go for it.  This game is still solid and truly holds up.  Meanwhile, if you have not played this game and are looking for something fun and relaxing, yet potentially challenging; I would say that you owe it to yourself to play this classic game.Please note:  The steam overlay does not work in this game.  Meaning you can not press shift + tab to look at friends, guides, achievements, etc, because of this Rollercoaster Tycoon does not support screenshots.  The resolution is off too - This game can not be played on full screen on my monitor.Now, go charge your guests a $100 entrance fee and overcharge on all food, drinks and rides!EDIT: This is a fantastic game that should win the "The Test of Time" award in the Steam Game Awards 2016!I also wanted the badge.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												This is my favourite game in the RCT series so it pains me not to recommend it. The game itself is brilliant, but sadly there are too many bugs in this port for new PC's. Its hit or miss whether the game will allow you to save, sometimes it will work fine and sometimes when you press the save button it will just crash to desktop. Sometimes when you launch the game it will crash on startup and sometimes it wont. As others have said, the game doesn't run in full screen mode (however, we're all using HD monitors these days and this was made in 1999, so not really the games fault that we still play it over 15 years later!) - If you're still running XP or have a retro gaming rig that supports steam then this game is well worth it. Sadly if you're running newer OS'es you will face problems (it seems to be the newer the OS the more problems it has, it used to work OKish for me on Win 7 but is pretty much unplayable on Win 10)

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												Let me begin by saying that I have been an avid Payday fan since the first installment starting around early 2013. I played the hell out of the first game and when I heard the second was on the way around April of 2013, I couldn't have been more excited. I put in a pre-order for the Career Criminal Edition and played the beta prior to release. Once the game came out, I dumped lots of time into it. Although I'd get burnt out on it and have to take breaks for about a week or two at a time, I kept coming back to it. I was always so inspired by the devs at Overkill to do like they had, and for the past few months my friend and I have been making our own game. It's not anything much at this point but people like Simon and Almir made me passionate about games and I chose to persue that path for myself. Watching this game evolve from the beginning has been incredible, and although it's had some bad moments, we can't deny that it has had some kickass moments as well. But not anymore. Now that Overkill has made the bright decision to put microtransactions into the game, I've never been more disappointed in them. The least they could've done is ignored the questions about microtransactions, but even so, going against their word is sickening. I can no longer recommend this masterpiece product to others because they turned it into♥♥♥♥♥♥with the addition of paying more money. I mean seriously, there's already enough DLC for this game to starve your bank account, and then they decide to pull this? I don't think so. Sorry Overkill, you guys really ♥♥♥♥ing blew it this time.

So buy it, but don't expect it to be the best version of the game. Still, for the price, it's good.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												Oh gosh, this game. It's fun. REALLY RUN. RollerCoaster Tycoon is about a game where you make rollercoasters or more specifically amusement parks who have rollercoasters in them. Your goal is to reach a certain amount of guests or park rating, among other things. The gameplay is simple. Make attractions, like rollercoasters, Go Karts, Log Flumes, etc., so your park can become more popular. You can charge people for many things, including to use the bathroom, which can be hilarious when they really need to go, but don't want to. However, doing things like that can make completing your objective harder, because people will complain about it, which will bring your park rating down. However, you can drown the unhappy people, which will bring your park rating up for some reason. However, there are some downsides. For example, on my laptop, almost EVERYTIME you close the game, my computer doesn't recognize any touches and FORCES you to shut down by using the power button. Also, the guests are WAY too scared. I made a rollercoaster that just goes down by not that much and it had an intensity meter of 11 and nobody would ride it, even though I made it free and advertised it. Also, NEVER save on the same save file. I did that and it stopped working, which was a world I spent 6 hours on.Final Verdict: 8/10+Fun+Replay Value+Years of entertainment+Addicting-Guests way too scared

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												A must-have classic. Excellent, addicting gameplay along with qualities apart from that that I certainly enjoy due to nostalgia, but newcomers may find off-putting. I find the audio pretty good, the graphics not as bad as they could be, and the GUI incredibly helpful if a little annoying at times.Steam integration has not been fully added at this time, but devs have promised an HD remaster in the future. So while we can enjoy this masterpiece as it was all those years ago (it's as old as me! and to think I played this so much when I was younger.), we can expect small improvements over time that should be not at all detrimental to the glorious gameplay.

A reminder that dreams are still possible, because it wasn’t that long ago that I was in a little town across the country sleeping on a couch in a mobile home with only forty seven dollars in my bank account. I didn’t have a college degree, I had no opportunities. But you know what? Something happened that changed my life. I bumped into a mentor. And another mentor. And a few more mentors. I found five mentors. And they showed me what they did to become multimillionaires. Again, it’s not just about money, it’s about the good life; health, wealth, love and happiness. And so I record a little video, it’s actually on my website, you can click here on this video and it’ll take you to my website where I share three things that they taught me. Three things that you can implement today no matter where you are. Now, this isn’t a “get rich quick” scheme. You know, like they say if things sound too good to be true they are too good to be true. I’m not promising you that tomorrow you’re gonna be able to go out and buy a Lamborghini. But what I am telling you is that it can happen faster than you think if you know the proven steps. So, I record a little two minute video on my website. Like I said, now it’s not the most professional I just shot it here with my iPhone, but it’s real. Nobody can argue, this is my true story. And I’m going to give you the three most important things you can do today. So click the link, go there it’s completely free to watch it it’s just a couple minutes. Invest in yourself. Always be curious. Don’t be a cynic. Okay, people see videos like this and they say “Ah that’s not real that’s for somebody else.” Don’t listen, don’t listen. Be an optimist. Like, Conrad Hilton, the man who started Hilton Hotel, he said that he was only fifteen years old when he read a book by Helen Keller, and that book changed his life. Books can change your life. And in that book, Helen Keller said “optimism” so if you’re a cynic, if you’re a pessimist you don’t need to click here. Don’t worry about it, I don’t need to talk to everybody. But if you’re somebody who knows that there’s something better, cause the dream is possible, you know, for some of you watching it’s not necessarily a Lamborghini, maybe it’s a new job, a new opportunity, starting your own company. Maybe it’s a new lifestyle without so much stress, traveling the world, doing those things you know you’re destined to do. You can do those unless you understand finances. Money, I don’t call it money anymore, I call it fuel units. You must have enough fuel units to live out your dream and to live out your destiny. So, I’ll see you on my website, it’s a quick video and you’ll see there absolutely free. So just click this video and you’ll be taken there in a second, and uh, I’m excited to share this amazing stuff. You’ll see, not because of anything of me but because I’ve been fortunate enough to learn from mentors many years ahead of me. Not just in books like these, although I love books but also real in-person mentors. So let me share with you these three tips that have made all the difference in my life. content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												Don't get me wrong, Roller Coaster Tycoon is an amazing game that you'll spend hours and hours playing. The issue is that the support for this game here on Steam is virtually non-existent.Some cons:- Most people cannot get fullscreen to work- Despite being in Window mode, you're unable to click outside the window and use the desktop most times- The Steam Overlay does not work- You can not take screenshots and upload them to the Steam Workshop- A small patch was recently released which broke everyones' progress in-game. No explanation or help was offered from any of the developers/CMs, and a crude "fix" for this had to be provided by one of the playersKeep in mind however that I'm not hating on the game itself. In fact, I love it. But if you're new to the series, or even if you're a returning player looking to get back into one of the best games of the 90's, I'd recommend getting this game someplace else or at least waiting until this game is properly supported.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												This game is exactly what it advertises itself to be and what you would likely expect it to be.I did enjoy the time I spent in game, however there is one (rather large in my opinion) problem with the game that leaves me unable to recommend it.In game everything works as it should, most if not every part of play is confiigurable from how much the admission cost of the park is to the time of the intervals your maintenance workers check the attractions you've built. On my first day playing I was quite content with it until I made the mistake of alt. tabbing to change the song I had playing in Chrome (heck after I messed with the game a little more today I've realized that even saving the game and closing out of it triggers this). Basically any time I leave the game's screen after starting, whether to alt. tab or turn the game off the input from my mouse is messed up. Basically I can interact with some things on my screen but not others. I can change the songs in my youtube playlist, but not what tab I'm on in Google chrome, and this affects more than just that as I also could not interact effectively with task manager. Just what you can't interact with seems to fluctuate some given time off the game but still makes normal use of my machine impossible. The only semi-decent workaround I've found to this is unplugging my mouse and plugging back in, and when I went back into the game today to see if this glitch would really happen every time I closed the game out or tried to tab away even unplugging my mouse and plugging it back in didn't work at first when the glitch inevitably did occur again. Which leaves me fearful for what it could actually be doing to my machine. While I assume it isn't really hurting my machine I'm not going to continue tempting the fates with it as I don't want to have get my computer fixed.While my overal experiance in playing the game was good, this glitch has made this game the epitomy of throwing five dollars at a wall as this game has proven itself to be one that I cannot play if I value my equipment.I'll be uninstalling this and I do not recommend this game.prosSimple, easy to playhighly configurabledecently pricedconsNo tutorials or hintsIn my case a large glitch that I do not want continuing.

number of helpful: 1 of 17 people (6%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												Completely frustrating game. Frankly, this game has made me realize I can't trust Steam reviews anymore, at least not in the aggregate. This game by any modern standards is terrible. Awful, clumsy interface. Level design that will make you pull your hair out. Controls are clunky. Ugly graphics, even considering its age.Why do people rate this so highly on Steam? Purely nostalgia. This is why I can't trust Steam reviews anymore. I understood that the graphics would be outdated, sure. But the gameplay, interface, level design, and controls should all have stood the test of time, right?No. I have to do so much tedious labor to do the simplest of tasks, such as leveling the ground, getting rid of trees (hint, you have to do it one click at a time), and making sure that the roller coaster pieces fit not only the slope of the ground, but each other. Simply, there is a lot that the programming should have taken care of for you. Did I really need to click on several different menus in order to 1. raise the slope 2. raise the tiles 3. place the tile or track 4. make sure it all exactly fits back at the beginning. Otherwise, start all the way over with a clunky arrow system to select the exact track you want to change out, rather than simply clicking on the piece you want to change. I can't count how many rollercoasters I've begun just to delete the entire thing because it would be easier to just start over than to figure out how to make it all fit in the end. Oh, by the way, the game timer will tick away as you figure out how to finally make the rollercoaster pieces come together. Level design is either very repetitive, or done in such a way to be completely frustrating. One level has a park that's a lovely garden. But in order to achieve the usual goals (park rating above X, number of guests above Y at a very specific date), you have to destroy all the loveliness. In other words, destroy the park and build yet another cookie cutter theme park that makes for good business in order to reach the level's objectives.Worst of all, you have to play every single repetitive little level in order to get to what you really want - a sandbox mode. Look, the reason why we all play this game is not to make fake money. It's to have a theme park that looks the way we want it. Right? So why not just give us the sandbox level to start with? I understand that the game developers want a learning curve. But right now, the thirty or so levels all feel like agonizing tutorial levels that I cannot skip. Interface involves so much unnecessary clicking. In addition, the little pictures that indicate different menus are not very intuitive. Poor design. And of course, the graphics are an eyesore. They're not just outdated. They're just plain ugly. I can play a very old game, such as the original Super Mario Bros. or Sonic the Hedgehog and appreciate the graphics for what it was in its heyday. Even if I can't, the lack of good graphics is compensated by good gameplay in a true classic. But as discussed above this is not the case in this game. I haven't yet tried the sequel (RCT2), but my guess is that's where the game developers actually fixed all the problems that drive me crazy. If you want a good theme park simulator, find another game. There are plenty out there.

Posted: May 29, 2014
												This is an awesome simulator of being a huge theme park tycoon and although there are some who would argue that the sequels are better, in my opinion the original is almost certainly the best. It's a really old game, but with the cost that it's currently at, it's well worth the price of admission. The main goal is to unlock all the maps by completing the set objectives by each individual map - obviously as time goes on, the maps get larger and larger and the potential for your park also grows.Apart from that - it's up to you! There are freeform maps where there aren't any set objectives and you can literally go wild without needing to stop. I honestly started playing this game on the original original Xbox and sadly that particular game couldn't be transferred onto the 360, but, as usual, Steam came to my rescue and the experience is miles better and the game is just as engaging as it was when it originally came out. If you get the chance to give it a go, I certainly reccomend this based on the price and the sheer addiction that forces 23 hours out of your day to day life.All good and nice, right? Well I have come across a pretty severe bug because for some reason after completing Trinity Islands last night, all my progress has been erased. Not my parks, but my progress; according to the game, I haven't completed one park, and yet according to my computer, I haven't lost a thing. I have no idea what the hell is going on, but I'm going to see if this is a permenant thing or if my computer is just being a♥♥♥♥♥♥because it's morning. In either case - buy this game for the really low price or even if it goes on offer [which is doubtful but Steam offers more packages than a postal delivery service, so it could happen].

												If you're looking at this game and you're wondering why it's so highly rated, you probably never played this as a kid, so you don't have nostalgia enhancing the experience. That's probably the biggest reason, and I'll admit that my review will likely be tinged with it.RollerCoaster Tycoon is an old game. It's older than one of my teenage younger sisters, which is actually not as old as I thought. (I was pretty sure I was only a year or two old when this came out. I guess I was five, at least when the deluxe version came out.) The graphics are dated, the gameplay is very simple, and money is apparently a million times more valuable because it's the late 90's. (I'm kidding. Sort of. I mean, you do start out with only $10k, and you still have enough to buy a few rides, so clearly something is off with the value.)I didn't actually grow up with this game, as far as I can remember. My parents were big on the Tycoon and Sims franchises, but I either wasn't allowed to play them or didn't care about them. But when I found the CD a few years ago, I decided to boot it up and give it a try. I was not disappointed.The game is really easy to pick up. You get some money, you get a clear objective (usually a number of guests and a certain park rating), and you get to work. The game is all about managing both your finances and guest happiness. The game makes it very easy to figure out what you need to do via guest feedback, and it's up to you to actually do it.Just because the game is simple, though, that doesn't mean it's boring or easy. Some of the later objectives get quite challenging, especially the park with no room for new rides. But even after you complete the challenges, it's still tons of fun to go back and continue to build up your park. You can have some pretty awesome parks going after four or five in-game years. Just sit back and watch the awards and the cash come flowing in!Oh, and if guests don't like you, you can drown them. No one else notices or helps, either, which is both amusing and disturbing. But it's a great way to boost park rating in small doses, and it's a sick sort of amusement.So, even if this game has no relevance to your childhood or your inner child, this still can be a fun game to go back to time and time again. Just make sure you set aside three hours or so for it. You will sit down, open the game, look at the clock, and realize that hours have gone by without you realizing it. That's why my playtime is so low on here--I've only gone back to it once, and I still accumulated over two hours of playtime. You can bet that I'll be playing it once the semester is over, however.P.S. As I mentioned, I still have the CD, but I saw this on here for under three bucks, so I decided to buy it. I didn't have the deluxe edition, so I got a bit more content, and the devs got some more money. It was a win-win.

Posted: July 17, 2014
												Before I get more in-depth, I'll explain my opinions on the RCT games for anyone unsure on what to get. If you're looking for a fun and challenging campaign-based RCT, buy this one. If you want lots of mods and custom scenarios to toy with, buy 2. And last, if you want MORE mods, more realistic theme park recreations, water parks, zoo parks, and lots of sandbox coaster building, buy 3. I think all are good, but each has its strong points. But anyways, this is the original RCT, with all the expansions and a bunch of fan-made tracks added on. To put it short, it's a good game. The only major problems with this version are its quirks when used with Windows 7 and 8. The game, from what I know, will only run in a square resolution unless you change the inner workings of the EXE. It can crash fairly often, for semi-random reasons. And my install sometimes glitches my desktop when I quit, forcing me to reboot. However, if you can look past some irritating glitches on newer OSes, then this is a must-have. For about the same price as a CD of the game, you get everything on it already on your hard drive, no CD insertion required. If you're a big RCT fan, then I'd say buy it.

Posted: May 29, 2014
												This is an awesome simulator of being a huge theme park tycoon and although there are some who would argue that the sequels are better, in my opinion the original is almost certainly the best. It's a really old game, but with the cost that it's currently at, it's well worth the price of admission. The main goal is to unlock all the maps by completing the set objectives by each individual map - obviously as time goes on, the maps get larger and larger and the potential for your park also grows.Apart from that - it's up to you! There are freeform maps where there aren't any set objectives and you can literally go wild without needing to stop. I honestly started playing this game on the original original Xbox and sadly that particular game couldn't be transferred onto the 360, but, as usual, Steam came to my rescue and the experience is miles better and the game is just as engaging as it was when it originally came out. If you get the chance to give it a go, I certainly reccomend this based on the price and the sheer addiction that forces 23 hours out of your day to day life.All good and nice, right? Well I have come across a pretty severe bug because for some reason after completing Trinity Islands last night, all my progress has been erased. Not my parks, but my progress; according to the game, I haven't completed one park, and yet according to my computer, I haven't lost a thing. I have no idea what the hell is going on, but I'm going to see if this is a permenant thing or if my computer is just being a♥♥♥♥♥♥because it's morning. In either case - buy this game for the really low price or even if it goes on offer [which is doubtful but Steam offers more packages than a postal delivery service, so it could happen].

												Such a nostalgia trip~Definitely still holds up as an easy building/management game that's great for all ages, beginners and experts alike. There's a lot of fun to be had starting up a little park then watching it grow slowly over time as you add stalls and rides and even build your own roller coasters. I absolutely love this game and remember playing it a lot as a kid (I still have the CD laying around, but I may or may not have lost it) and its sequel RollerCoaster Tycoon 2 adds to the experience in so many lovely ways~But since I played RCT1 much, much more than 2, I have to say that this is my favorite entry to the series with the second game nearly tying. RCT 3 was an interesting jump into 3D that added quite a bit and changed things up, but you can just never beat a classic~ Plus this game works on almost any computer due to its 2D nature and sprite-art, so I'm sure it'd work on a toaster if you had the right OS.Buy the game if you like management genres, but don't expect the deepest of intricacies.

												this game has enough nostalgia to make me sit at the title screen and listen to the theme music for a good 10-15 seconds before i actually play. my childhood and stuff. when i do play it, i play it for 3 hours straight or not at all. part of this is because you can't speed up the time scale of the game (it's old school or something), but mostly i just get lost for 20 minutes building a single rollercoaster because that♥♥♥♥♥♥i hard. the game also doesn't have steam overlay (♥♥♥♥ing 1999 man) so i have to minimize it to check the time on my computer, which means i have no awareness of time passage. it's really good though. the nostalgia is validated by the impressive content and detail that is in the game. the detail adds a lot of realism and interesting mechanics. building coasters, for example, that scare your customers on sight won't have much business and a coaster that inches along the track at speeds an agoraphobic wouldn't be intimidated by won't bring customers either. the content includes a big variety of rides, many of which aren't rollercoasters (half of the rides probably are roller coasters though). there are water rides, gentle rides like merry-go-rounds, thrill rides like swinging ships, and a variety of shops and stalls. the incorporation of many different elements creates a genuine experience of running a themepark. the game comes with something like 100+ scenarios; they are like campaigns with specific goals, such as reaching a certain company value at the end of october (it's always october for some reason) in year x. the scenarios are pretty difficult and time consuming. given the content, you can spend immense amounts of time working through those alone. not too bad for isometric 1999.

												First off it is a shame that there is no middle option for a review because this game is great and you should buy it... but it has one big flaw that lets it down hugely (skip to the bottom to see what that is if you don't want to read the whole thing.I would like to say that this is the type of game that makes you sit back and think "I havn't played a game this fun and simple and really enjoyable in years", it is made to be fun which is a word not usually heard in video gaming these days.As this is a game that you can buy on disc i will compare it to the disc version but first lets talk about the game on its own: It is a very happy game and definatly cheers me up, running a theme park is wierdly enjoyable and when you win the guests all clap for you (which is so cute, also if they are holding a balloon they let go and it fly's into the air (simply joys)), it has many different parks with a lot of variety in goals and map types, the graphics are still decent and the little sweeping activity the handmen do is very sweet, and if you are a phycopath then forcing the rides to fall off the rails makes a great explosion.Now lets start comparing Pros of Steam version: It has a lot more variety of maps includng real world parks, there are more variety of rides, making banners is fun, also (only fans of the disc version will understand) you can set the price of all the burger stand to be the same price and not have to go round changing them all.Cons of the steam version:  It may just be with my version but you can't see what the rides will look like untill they are built (except for the original rides that were on the original disc version) this is very annoying as i don't know what the ride is at all or if it will be similar to previous rides i have or if it will be too extreme for my guests. Posted: October 25, 2015
												When it comes to the RTS (Real-Time Strategy) gaming genre, there are quite a few games that have left their mark. From the Command and Conquer series to Blizzard greats like Starcraft, or Warcraft, there are plenty of options when it comes to combat-style RTS games. Roller Coaster Tycoon, however, took things in a whole new direction and this is why it's in the spotlight for this BTN Gaming Review.     Now Roller Coaster Tycoon, upon arrival, totally reshaped the way people look at RTS games. In fact, it really created a whole new sub-genre in the Real-Time category. While the player doesn't necessarily control every aspect of the game, they do have control over the most key features. This is just one of the many details that makes Roller Coaster Tycoon stand out from its predecessors. Another key aspect, and quite possibly the one that carried the most impact, is the simple yet detail-oriented style of play. It's a very relaxed game in the fact that there isn't an enemy on the map who is ready to pillage and plunder you for everything you've got, but that's not to say that it doesn't have its own edge. Roller Coaster Tycoon delivers its thrills in a much more intricate and subtle way. It's these exact features that make it a great game, while at the same time might give a newcomer some frustrations.     For starters, Roller Coaster Tycoon's maps (campaign?) is a series of challenging theme parks that all have a certain goal that must be obtained. Whether it's building a brand new park from scratch, obtaining a specific park value, or even just to up the rating of an already thriving theme park, every single level in Roller Coaster Tycoon is wrapped around achieving these goals. Once these goals are achieved, a new map is opened up and the player can progress further on down the line. This is a great feature because it keeps the player interested with new scenes, new objectives, and really fills out the experience with the many different types of obstacles that can be overcome. However, it's this exact reason that might deter the more "casual" player. The reason for this is the simple fact that there is no sandbox mode. Not only is there the void of sandboxing but there is also this... nagging urge to just quit a park once the objective has been completed. If the player decides to save the current progress on any park once achieving the goal, they can return to it at any point in time.... but there really isn't much of a need to do so. This can severely cut the replay value of the game short, and while it isn't the biggest problem in the world, it can still be considered when arriving at the decision to purchase the game.     While the goal-oriented gameplay of Roller Coaster Tycoon is great, jaded only by the lack of a sandbox freeplay mode, we can't forget the details. Literally, the details. Roller Coaster Tycoon is absolutely FILLED to the brim with detail-oriented time management, and it's in these details that Roller Coaster Tycoon really thrives. From being able to design the roller coaster of your dreams, down the simplest detail as simply painting every ice cream shop a different color, it's these little intricacies that drive the game. That said, it's also these very minute, albeit important, features can become daunting at certain points in the game. For instance, when it comes to building said "Dream Roller Coaster" the game will not allow it to be built unless all of the brakes and speedups are in the right place. Prices too high for ice cream? Well that will drive potential patrons away before you even get the chance to fix it. So with that said, it's quite easy to get lost in the details and if things start getting to difficult to understand, just remember: breathe and if all else fails, RESTART!    On that note, however, there is also lack of any sort of tutorial or information that is in-game to help the player, should they feel lost. Don't get me wrong, I completely enjoy playing a game and feeling it out without any sort of help system at all. That's why I do what I do! But there are other players out there who don't want to mess around with understanding the mechanics or explore and experiment... simply put they want to achieve that goal for the next map. This is why some sort of help system within the actual framework of the game would be a huge help. For instance, your rating is dropping too low and you are just two months away from getting that coveted pat on the back for achieving an overall rating of 875 and you are sitting on 725. How do you get that rating up? Do you build more attractions? Do you lower the gate price? Do you run promotions? None of these answers are found directly in the game, not even in the help section. Thankfully though, there are pioneers out there who are willing and ready to write guides on issues such as this! That said, at least this information shouldn't be hard to find.     Overall, Roller Coaster Tycoon is a great little game, especially if the player is just looking to relax and chill out with a non-stressful game. All of its features can be seen as a double-edged sword so to speak, and if you are planning on buying the game, just make sure to take these things into consideration.For more information on this game, or to buy it yourself, please visit:Be sure to check out my other content!YouTube: http://www.youtube.com/channel/UC9wBb1EsrvF6mEPTWD1d0qABlog: http://btngaminggamereviews.blogspot.com/Tumblr: http://bringthenoisegaming.tumblr.com/Follow me on Twitter: @BTN_Gaming

Posted: June 25, 2015
												Prior to purchasing it on Steam, I put endless hours into this game as a kid and at many recurring points in my life. Even now as an adult I find myself completely addicted to it.I definitely think these types of games are catered to a specific type of person, though. Some people will simply look at this and think it's boring or too niche. So if you're unsure about purchasing it and already feel like you won't like it then you're probably right. As for me I love everything about it.I love organizing things. I love micro-management simulators. I love games where you start with nothing and very gradually work your way up to the top. A lot of people play RollerCoaster Tycoon because they think it's fun to make horrific, nightmare-esque theme parks in which people die and their ratings plummet right off the bat. I can understand the appeal of this but I honestly adore this game for exactly what it's trying to be. The better you do at running your park the more attractions you unlock. You can reshape the landscape, choose what stalls and shops will be available for your guests, hire a specific number of employees, and of course decide exactly which rides you want to include and place them exactly where you want them.Whenever I meet the goals of a level I feel a unique sense of silly pride at doing so--but pride nonetheless.I dunno. I just find everything about this game extremely satisfying.

Posted: February 8, 2016
												The original Rollercoaster Tycoon was an awesome game.   It was a giant sandbox for you to build your own theme park, design your own coasters (as well as log rides and go-kart tracks), charge however much you wanted, and expand your park empire across the globe.  The best part is that the game has aged quite well.  It's still awesome to design your own coaster, including color scheme and even the music that plays as people line up to ride it (even importing your own music if you wish!).  The games many challenges will keep you busy for a long time as well.  There's so many small details that make this game great, like paying attentions to the staff you hire, making sure to eject trouble makers in the park, making sure there's restrooms for patrons (you can even charge for access to the restroom!), keeping up with ride maintenance, and making sure your latest coaster isn't a deathtrap.  It's worth the low purchase price for the many hours you will get out of this if you haven't played it before.

Posted: October 25, 2015
												When it comes to the RTS (Real-Time Strategy) gaming genre, there are quite a few games that have left their mark. From the Command and Conquer series to Blizzard greats like Starcraft, or Warcraft, there are plenty of options when it comes to combat-style RTS games. Roller Coaster Tycoon, however, took things in a whole new direction and this is why it's in the spotlight for this BTN Gaming Review.     Now Roller Coaster Tycoon, upon arrival, totally reshaped the way people look at RTS games. In fact, it really created a whole new sub-genre in the Real-Time category. While the player doesn't necessarily control every aspect of the game, they do have control over the most key features. This is just one of the many details that makes Roller Coaster Tycoon stand out from its predecessors. Another key aspect, and quite possibly the one that carried the most impact, is the simple yet detail-oriented style of play. It's a very relaxed game in the fact that there isn't an enemy on the map who is ready to pillage and plunder you for everything you've got, but that's not to say that it doesn't have its own edge. Roller Coaster Tycoon delivers its thrills in a much more intricate and subtle way. It's these exact features that make it a great game, while at the same time might give a newcomer some frustrations.     For starters, Roller Coaster Tycoon's maps (campaign?) is a series of challenging theme parks that all have a certain goal that must be obtained. Whether it's building a brand new park from scratch, obtaining a specific park value, or even just to up the rating of an already thriving theme park, every single level in Roller Coaster Tycoon is wrapped around achieving these goals. Once these goals are achieved, a new map is opened up and the player can progress further on down the line. This is a great feature because it keeps the player interested with new scenes, new objectives, and really fills out the experience with the many different types of obstacles that can be overcome. However, it's this exact reason that might deter the more "casual" player. The reason for this is the simple fact that there is no sandbox mode. Not only is there the void of sandboxing but there is also this... nagging urge to just quit a park once the objective has been completed. If the player decides to save the current progress on any park once achieving the goal, they can return to it at any point in time.... but there really isn't much of a need to do so. This can severely cut the replay value of the game short, and while it isn't the biggest problem in the world, it can still be considered when arriving at the decision to purchase the game.     While the goal-oriented gameplay of Roller Coaster Tycoon is great, jaded only by the lack of a sandbox freeplay mode, we can't forget the details. Literally, the details. Roller Coaster Tycoon is absolutely FILLED to the brim with detail-oriented time management, and it's in these details that Roller Coaster Tycoon really thrives. From being able to design the roller coaster of your dreams, down the simplest detail as simply painting every ice cream shop a different color, it's these little intricacies that drive the game. That said, it's also these very minute, albeit important, features can become daunting at certain points in the game. For instance, when it comes to building said "Dream Roller Coaster" the game will not allow it to be built unless all of the brakes and speedups are in the right place. Prices too high for ice cream? Well that will drive potential patrons away before you even get the chance to fix it. So with that said, it's quite easy to get lost in the details and if things start getting to difficult to understand, just remember: breathe and if all else fails, RESTART!    On that note, however, there is also lack of any sort of tutorial or information that is in-game to help the player, should they feel lost. Don't get me wrong, I completely enjoy playing a game and feeling it out without any sort of help system at all. That's why I do what I do! But there are other players out there who don't want to mess around with understanding the mechanics or explore and experiment... simply put they want to achieve that goal for the next map. This is why some sort of help system within the actual framework of the game would be a huge help. For instance, your rating is dropping too low and you are just two months away from getting that coveted pat on the back for achieving an overall rating of 875 and you are sitting on 725. How do you get that rating up? Do you build more attractions? Do you lower the gate price? Do you run promotions? None of these answers are found directly in the game, not even in the help section. Thankfully though, there are pioneers out there who are willing and ready to write guides on issues such as this! That said, at least this information shouldn't be hard to find.     Overall, Roller Coaster Tycoon is a great little game, especially if the player is just looking to relax and chill out with a non-stressful game. All of its features can be seen as a double-edged sword so to speak, and if you are planning on buying the game, just make sure to take these things into consideration.For more information on this game, or to buy it yourself, please visit:Be sure to check out my other content!YouTube: http://www.youtube.com/channel/UC9wBb1EsrvF6mEPTWD1d0qABlog: http://btngaminggamereviews.blogspot.com/Tumblr: http://bringthenoisegaming.tumblr.com/Follow me on Twitter: @BTN_Gaming

												It was a stormy summers eve when I bought this game. My childhood memories of this game overtook me with nostalgia and forced me to press "Buy". I installed the game and watched it boot up, the carnival music filling the room as the rain beat against the window outside. I start a new game, and descended into Hell. I broke all the rides, drowned all the children, every bathroom had a fee of fifty dollars and the exit was closed, trapping everyone in my eternal damnation. The food was infested with flies and the security guards were nowhere to be found. The entertainers robbed the customers before they all huddled inside the haunted house and sacrificed them to the dark lord. My greatest dreams came true, thanks to this game. 10/10, would recommend.

Posted: September 25, 2014
												This game is incredible, just keep in mind it takes a lot of patience to get through.  A one year scenario takes 50 minutes, 3 years scenarios ~3 hours.  There are 60 scenarios in this pack, which means there is probably around 120 hours of content in the game, without playing any scenarios twice, and assuming you know what you are doing. For those who haven't played the game yet, it takes some time to get used to, I would strongly recommend you look at a tutorial, or you will miss incredibly important parts of the GUI that are very easy to notice, for example, research, advertising, and loans.  If you have time and patience to learn, you won't be dissapointed by this game.

Posted: September 26, 2014
												A favotite from my childhood, and seeing it come to steam has made me fall in love with the game once more.For those that have not played the game or any on the sequals, the game revolves around building a theme park in one of a numerous range of landscapes. Though most of the parks are locked at the start and require unlocking by completing previous parks and tasks (which can be quite time consuming), I find this a point to work towards that you don't get in the second game.The selection of rides is rather stunted in this version, and some of the landscapes don't really make for great/vast parks like in the second or even third so most parks end up feeling the same. The only reason I would not recomend this game OR you are new to the series; is because RollerCoaster tycoon 2 does everything the first does but better. However this is one game that I would recomend to a vast crowd and it is a great, fun game to play to pass the time.

Posted: June 6, 2015
												Roller Coaster Tycoon is, and will always be, a gaming classic. The premise is simple, start with a park, build up rides and attractions, and achieve a goal. Along the way when you get money you can buy roller coasters.....lots and lots of roller coaster to choose from! Chris Sawyer, the developer of this game, knew that simplicity was key, and it was that that makes this the most fun game you can ever play.

Posted: May 29, 2014
												This is an awesome simulator of being a huge theme park tycoon and although there are some who would argue that the sequels are better, in my opinion the original is almost certainly the best. It's a really old game, but with the cost that it's currently at, it's well worth the price of admission. The main goal is to unlock all the maps by completing the set objectives by each individual map - obviously as time goes on, the maps get larger and larger and the potential for your park also grows.Apart from that - it's up to you! There are freeform maps where there aren't any set objectives and you can literally go wild without needing to stop. I honestly started playing this game on the original original Xbox and sadly that particular game couldn't be transferred onto the 360, but, as usual, Steam came to my rescue and the experience is miles better and the game is just as engaging as it was when it originally came out. If you get the chance to give it a go, I certainly reccomend this based on the price and the sheer addiction that forces 23 hours out of your day to day life.All good and nice, right? Well I have come across a pretty severe bug because for some reason after completing Trinity Islands last night, all my progress has been erased. Not my parks, but my progress; according to the game, I haven't completed one park, and yet according to my computer, I haven't lost a thing. I have no idea what the hell is going on, but I'm going to see if this is a permenant thing or if my computer is just being a♥♥♥♥♥♥because it's morning. In either case - buy this game for the really low price or even if it goes on offer [which is doubtful but Steam offers more packages than a postal delivery service, so it could happen].

Posted: April 11, 2015
												My room mate recently started replaying this game and seeing as Steam had it I bought it and started playing it again as well. Ahhh~ The nolstagia is strong with this game. Your main goal with this game is to build up and maintain a them park while following the guidelines of each level. Some start you from scratch, others don't. Anyway, it's a simple but complicated game as most Management type games go. For instance, can't make a roller coaster too scary or hardly anyone will ride it but if it's too weak, no one will want to ride it because it's not intense enough. Just be sure to Test Run your ride first to make sure it isn't a death trap. I've accidentally killed some people because I forgot to do that first. >_> Sometimes it's really hard to know if what you're building will appeal to your guests, but once you've got it right, advertise the crap out of your new ride, and watch the dollars signs fly up.Anyway, this game is enjoyable and relaxing. If you likebuilding and maintaining and feeling powerful because you know how to maintain a park and make big bucks doing it, then this game is for you. P.S. If you click on a stray balloon it will pop and if you click on a duck, it will quack. I didn't know about these fun little Easter Eggs until I bought it on Steam so I thought I would share that with you. :) Have fun!

Posted: April 21, 2015
												This game teaches you how to be a capitalist: Your goal is to continuously expand you park even though you have a limited ammount of land to do so. This is in order for you to then gain the money in order to pay back the backs the loans you start with and then once you've done so, just accumulate money until you've run out of room in you park at which point you suddenly become hommicdal and set out to drown everyone until any body of water that you've placed into, or that is in your park becomes an open cemmitary. Now you gain money by investing in your park by purchasing rides/consumor points, investing in advertisment campaings and charging people to use the toilets so the 20% of all guests who go on your roller coasters can throw up into a tolet instead of on the pavement making you hier jannitors to clean it up. This game also teaches you that there's no negative reprocussions to actions that due to your own fault injur, annoy or kill any of your guests and you'll be rewarded the "safest parkin the country" so long as you have "Furguson Missouri" levels of police. But if one ride crashes and blows up (which is out of your control) then your population levels drop faster than a gold digger at the sight of a £20 note. The game give you goals for each park as well just to give you a purpose in this game and infact life.Honestly though this game, Fifa Street, Lego Football mania and NEED FOR MADNESS? was my childhood and I will definatly recomend this game because it's on steam. However the game crashes for me most of the time when I exit the game and you can't Shift+Tab for the steam bootstrapper while in game. But this is a must own game.

There is still a good balance of progressive challenges in maintaining the parks. Don't understaff your janitors in your park!

Posted: November 4, 2015
												Such a nostalgia trip~Definitely still holds up as an easy building/management game that's great for all ages, beginners and experts alike. There's a lot of fun to be had starting up a little park then watching it grow slowly over time as you add stalls and rides and even build your own roller coasters. I absolutely love this game and remember playing it a lot as a kid (I still have the CD laying around, but I may or may not have lost it) and its sequel RollerCoaster Tycoon 2 adds to the experience in so many lovely ways~But since I played RCT1 much, much more than 2, I have to say that this is my favorite entry to the series with the second game nearly tying. RCT 3 was an interesting jump into 3D that added quite a bit and changed things up, but you can just never beat a classic~ Plus this game works on almost any computer due to its 2D nature and sprite-art, so I'm sure it'd work on a toaster if you had the right OS.Buy the game if you like management genres, but don't expect the deepest of intricacies.

Posted: November 4, 2015
												this game has enough nostalgia to make me sit at the title screen and listen to the theme music for a good 10-15 seconds before i actually play. my childhood and stuff. when i do play it, i play it for 3 hours straight or not at all. part of this is because you can't speed up the time scale of the game (it's old school or something), but mostly i just get lost for 20 minutes building a single rollercoaster because that♥♥♥♥♥♥i hard. the game also doesn't have steam overlay (♥♥♥♥ing 1999 man) so i have to minimize it to check the time on my computer, which means i have no awareness of time passage. it's really good though. the nostalgia is validated by the impressive content and detail that is in the game. the detail adds a lot of realism and interesting mechanics. building coasters, for example, that scare your customers on sight won't have much business and a coaster that inches along the track at speeds an agoraphobic wouldn't be intimidated by won't bring customers either. the content includes a big variety of rides, many of which aren't rollercoasters (half of the rides probably are roller coasters though). there are water rides, gentle rides like merry-go-rounds, thrill rides like swinging ships, and a variety of shops and stalls. the incorporation of many different elements creates a genuine experience of running a themepark. the game comes with something like 100+ scenarios; they are like campaigns with specific goals, such as reaching a certain company value at the end of october (it's always october for some reason) in year x. the scenarios are pretty difficult and time consuming. given the content, you can spend immense amounts of time working through those alone. not too bad for isometric 1999.

Posted: March 20, 2015
												I can easily say that this game was my childhood. I bought the game at the full price of $6 because I decided I couldn't wait until it went on sale, and honestly I regret it.Immediately upon launching it for the very first time, it caused my laptop's video driver to crash. I was a little alarmed as my laptop is stronger than many gaming desktops out there, but brushed it off once a restart of my laptop got it working. Immediately I was reminded why I loved this game: it's fun and reminded me of everything that I used to love about the RollerCoaster series.Downloading and launching the game on my desktop the following day, I was pleased when there were no problems... except why can't I play it in fullscreen? Ah well, I'll deal with it, at least it didn't crash funny on me like it did on my laptop.Well then I encountered the horror story that I had read in a review - the 'save crash'. Upon saving my game after playing for two hours it crashed on me. Immediately the idea of logging back into that game and re-doing everything I  had just done  was frustrating. But ultimately the part that really bothered me was Steams support for the game - read the supreme  lack  of support. Going through the support site here on Steam just wanted me to contact Atari.Looking back, I feel that these were probably bugs that had been present in my original RCT, I vaguely remember problems with fullscreen mode working, and I definitely remember a video crash or too - at the time I had assumed it was my very, very outdated computer (it was classified as outdated in  2000  so it was definitely rather basic). The fact that these errors actually continued on to Steam was disheartening. I currently have an old scratched up CD of RCT; the reason I didn't shove that into my desktop and download it there was because I'd wrongly assumed that the one here would have these errors corrected. That was my fault.Now, I'm not saying that the game is horrible - At the time of writing this I've put 4 hours into it, and I will continue to play. However, I would  highly  recommend waiting until it's on sale.

												In Grand Theft Auto, you can kill people by hitting them with a car or shoot them with a gunin Roller Coaster Tycoon you can kill people by drowning them, or let them ride a roller coaster without trackby the way, this game was made using assembly language. yes ASSEMBLY!, that ASSEMBLY! the freakin low-level language. That 0x00001111 language. I really don't get how can Chris Sawyer make a game using assembly... ALONE?Say what you want about Dragon Age Inquisition, Destiny, or Crysis. In terms of optimization (for 90s PC) nothing can beat this game.START:   mov eax ,10   mov ebx, 10   div ebxEND STARTwould make a roller coaster of death again

Posted: June 30, 2014
												[Solved] Windows 7 64-Bit black screen w/ music problem: Initially, the program would load and would display only a low res/ color bit screen with the classic rollercoaster startup music in the background. The problem was isolated to a driver issue with the radeon 7760m graphics card. To solve, switched to intel hd 3000 graphics and ran program as admin with vista sp2 compat mode. No other issues since, great game!

Posted: November 26, 2016
												For over 15 years, this game has been one that is always on my favorite games list.  If gaming has an equivalent of comfort foods, then this is mine.  Every computer I have ever owned has had this game installed on it at some point.  I'm not sure if it is the nostalgia, but I swear this game holds up like no other, both in gameplay and aesthetics.  The game is great for all ages, it's very easy to pick up and play and thankfully there isn't a very big learning curve.  It also offers more in depth gameplay for those who want to manage everything including wheter or not to charge to use the restrooms.  I always like to charge at entry and make my rides free, but you could easily play the opposite way, there are just so many options.  Come to think of it I have little to no complaints about this game, which I think is most impresive.  The only thing I ever find annoying is the guest tend to get a little lost when you make paths double width.  In conclusion, I cannot recommend this game enough.

Posted: November 30, 2015
												If you're looking at this game and you're wondering why it's so highly rated, you probably never played this as a kid, so you don't have nostalgia enhancing the experience. That's probably the biggest reason, and I'll admit that my review will likely be tinged with it.RollerCoaster Tycoon is an old game. It's older than one of my teenage younger sisters, which is actually not as old as I thought. (I was pretty sure I was only a year or two old when this came out. I guess I was five, at least when the deluxe version came out.) The graphics are dated, the gameplay is very simple, and money is apparently a million times more valuable because it's the late 90's. (I'm kidding. Sort of. I mean, you do start out with only $10k, and you still have enough to buy a few rides, so clearly something is off with the value.)I didn't actually grow up with this game, as far as I can remember. My parents were big on the Tycoon and Sims franchises, but I either wasn't allowed to play them or didn't care about them. But when I found the CD a few years ago, I decided to boot it up and give it a try. I was not disappointed.The game is really easy to pick up. You get some money, you get a clear objective (usually a number of guests and a certain park rating), and you get to work. The game is all about managing both your finances and guest happiness. The game makes it very easy to figure out what you need to do via guest feedback, and it's up to you to actually do it.Just because the game is simple, though, that doesn't mean it's boring or easy. Some of the later objectives get quite challenging, especially the park with no room for new rides. But even after you complete the challenges, it's still tons of fun to go back and continue to build up your park. You can have some pretty awesome parks going after four or five in-game years. Just sit back and watch the awards and the cash come flowing in!Oh, and if guests don't like you, you can drown them. No one else notices or helps, either, which is both amusing and disturbing. But it's a great way to boost park rating in small doses, and it's a sick sort of amusement.So, even if this game has no relevance to your childhood or your inner child, this still can be a fun game to go back to time and time again. Just make sure you set aside three hours or so for it. You will sit down, open the game, look at the clock, and realize that hours have gone by without you realizing it. That's why my playtime is so low on here--I've only gone back to it once, and I still accumulated over two hours of playtime. You can bet that I'll be playing it once the semester is over, however.P.S. As I mentioned, I still have the CD, but I saw this on here for under three bucks, so I decided to buy it. I didn't have the deluxe edition, so I got a bit more content, and the devs got some more money. It was a win-win.

Posted: December 19, 2015
												Whenever I think of an amazing old game. This one comes to mind. This has been my favorite game ever since the DEMO came out. RollerCoaster Tycoon is all about building and managing your own amusement park. Not only can you customize rollercoaster, go-kart tracks and other tracked rides; but you can also customize prices for everything from the rides, to the staff, to the restrooms. The entire park is pretty much at your finger-tips.You can build yourself any coaster you can imagine, though your 'peeps' won't always want to ride them. If they're too intense, or not intense enough. Same with all the rides and prices. These guys have preferences, and stick to them rather heavily.It's impossible to do this game justice in a simple text review. If you have any interest in financial simulators, you should get this game. Can't go wrong for the price Steam is offering either.

Posted: February 8, 2016
												The original Rollercoaster Tycoon was an awesome game.   It was a giant sandbox for you to build your own theme park, design your own coasters (as well as log rides and go-kart tracks), charge however much you wanted, and expand your park empire across the globe.  The best part is that the game has aged quite well.  It's still awesome to design your own coaster, including color scheme and even the music that plays as people line up to ride it (even importing your own music if you wish!).  The games many challenges will keep you busy for a long time as well.  There's so many small details that make this game great, like paying attentions to the staff you hire, making sure to eject trouble makers in the park, making sure there's restrooms for patrons (you can even charge for access to the restroom!), keeping up with ride maintenance, and making sure your latest coaster isn't a deathtrap.  It's worth the low purchase price for the many hours you will get out of this if you haven't played it before.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												It was a stormy summers eve when I bought this game. My childhood memories of this game overtook me with nostalgia and forced me to press "Buy". I installed the game and watched it boot up, the carnival music filling the room as the rain beat against the window outside. I start a new game, and descended into Hell. I broke all the rides, drowned all the children, every bathroom had a fee of fifty dollars and the exit was closed, trapping everyone in my eternal damnation. The food was infested with flies and the security guards were nowhere to be found. The entertainers robbed the customers before they all huddled inside the haunted house and sacrificed them to the dark lord. My greatest dreams came true, thanks to this game. 10/10, would recommend.

Posted: July 28, 2016
												I remember playing this game years and years ago, and had such a good time messing around in a park. I couldn't install it from disc on modern operating systems anymore, so I lost sight of it until the Steam Sale of this year. I immediately got this edition and all the nostalgia rushed back at me. This game is very realistic and challenging, despite it being already sixteen years old. You need to be able to handle money and guest needs in order to reach the goal in every scenario. Do you loan more money? Would you rather custom build your own coasters or use prebuilt ones? Do you have enough mechanics and handymen to keep your park in working order? Are the guests happy? There is a lot to take into consideration, and that is what makes this game fun to play over and over again. Even after finishing a scenario you can simply try again differently if you wish. With many scenarios present in the Deluxe Edition, some with blank parks and some with pre-built parks, you can have a lot of fun.For me it works on Windows 8 in fullscreen mode.

Posted: August 23, 2016
												Note: Ive owned this game since it came out, and have far more than 20 or so hours actually invested into itRollercoaster Tycoon 1 is a phenominal theme park sim. You basically just get to build and manage a theme park, either one thats already mostly built, or one you make from scratch. For a game from 1999, the graphics hold up quite well, and I havnt had any real issues running this. For reference, Im currently using a laptop running Win7. The music isnt bad, it can just get a little stale after playing for hours at a time. Honestly, I own Rollercoaster Tycoon 1, 2, and three, with all of the DLC, and this one is the one I return to the most. Pro's:Super funEasy to learn, but difficult to masterNice graphicsCan easily sink 100+ hours into this gameCon's:Music gets repetitive after a while, but can muteGame is almost 20 years old, can have issues on newer systemsCan easily sink 100+ hours into this game

Posted: July 10, 2016
												Holy ♥♥♥♥ing♥♥♥♥♥♥I love this game. The extreme intense gameplay puts me on the edge of my seat at almost every moment. The graphics are breathtaking and ageless, and the amazing animations that show how the roller coasters represent the true feeling of the second world war accurately. This is one of the best FPS, puzzle, rpg, and bullethell games I have ever seen. Truely a classic.

Posted: July 28, 2016
												I remember playing this game years and years ago, and had such a good time messing around in a park. I couldn't install it from disc on modern operating systems anymore, so I lost sight of it until the Steam Sale of this year. I immediately got this edition and all the nostalgia rushed back at me. This game is very realistic and challenging, despite it being already sixteen years old. You need to be able to handle money and guest needs in order to reach the goal in every scenario. Do you loan more money? Would you rather custom build your own coasters or use prebuilt ones? Do you have enough mechanics and handymen to keep your park in working order? Are the guests happy? There is a lot to take into consideration, and that is what makes this game fun to play over and over again. Even after finishing a scenario you can simply try again differently if you wish. With many scenarios present in the Deluxe Edition, some with blank parks and some with pre-built parks, you can have a lot of fun.For me it works on Windows 8 in fullscreen mode.

Posted: August 22, 2016
												If Steam existed 15 years ago, I would have thousands upon thousands of hours logged in this game. I've played this game all my life and nothing parallels it to me. I've never been one to build "death parks" or drown hundrds of guests at once (though believe me, I have at one point or another), but I can lose myself for hours managing my assets and maximizing profits through every little data point the game lets you tweak and customize. It's the perfect mix of art and science - though it takes a while to get the hang of balancing costs and profits, every level offers room for creativity in working with the space given to you and designing crazy coasters to attract new visitors. As a perfectionist with OCD, nothing satisfies me more than seeing all the tiny tweaks and behind-the-scenes minutia add up to a park full of happy customers, and hearing all the delighted screams and chatter mixed with rushing coasters and the iconic Merry-Go-Round music. For my money, this is the best game ever made.

Posted: May 6, 2015
												Please do not let the time fool you I have hundreds of hours in this game. Have had this game on disc since it came out. This game is absolutely great. People I see complaining about "no remastering, no retouching, nothing new" can honestly go to [redacted]. This game doesn't need it. It was great back then, and it is still great now. It may be simple and it may have its issues, but that is honestly what makes it great. The parks and their objectives range from easy to challenging. What is better however is playing the parks after the objectives conclude. Some of them have so much expansion room that you can double or triple the size of the original park. Honestly, many of the parks only come into their own after the objectives have been completed because if you stay with them, what you can research and what you can build is just great. The only reason I have the steam version, plus low time, is because it was on sale and because I wanted to play them on my newer computers. Still have an old XP desktop with my original game and about 90% of the parks unlocked.

Posted: May 5, 2015
												I've literally been playing this game since I was 12(28 now), and every time I sit down to play again it is as charming as ever. I also find that I play it a little bit differently each time, finding new ways to be successful , which to me, is one of the things that makes the game so interesting. There really isn't a right or wrong way to play, and even after all this time there are still people sharing their designs online, whether they be for rides or parks, which is fairly unique. This package is so great, not just because of the price, but because it includes both expansion packs as well. The original stand alone game is deep on it's own, even by today's standards, but with the additional attractions and scenarios the game basically expands to 3 games in one.When you think of if that way, it's basically the price of 3 good apps for your smartphone.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												This game is honestly one of my favorite games of all time. I've sunk probably a couple thousand hours into this game throughout my entire life (Don't let the steam hours fool you), with both the regular and deluxe editions. Everything about this game ranges from great to perfect. This game has one of the most memorable soundtracks I've ever heard, with everything from the title theme to the music tracks that the rides can play. The game itself is incredibly simplistic, with the interface being easy to navigate and control, but still has enough complexity in how you have to manage everything in order to properly meet your objectives, and stay out of debt. It also has tons of replayability, and it takes a long time in order for it to actually become boring. The difficulty is the only thing remotely negative that I feel that this game has, and the only reason I feel this way is because it doesn't really have much consistency with how it progresses, as some parks early on will be more difficult than ones that you end up unlocking later from completing more parks' objectives. The Scores  Gameplay  : 9/10 Audio  : 10/10 Visuals  : 8/10 Difficulty  : 6/10 Overall: 8.5 / 10 A great game that has withstood the test of time for over 17 years.Would reccomend to anyone who enjoys simulation games, or just wants a fun little time waster.

												With the new Planet Coasters game and the latest RollerCoaster Tycoon having just been released, I felt some nostalgia to go back and play a bit of this one. I played it a lot years ago, an it's still a great game to this day. This game really sets the standard for a park sim. It's approachable for a new player to just go in and start throwing coasters and other rides around, but you will quickly realize the level of depth there is to the park management. From keeping eye on customer satisfaction with pricing per ride, to promotions to increase interest in your park, this game packs some fine details for being the first release in the series. If you're not sure you're into park sims, this is a great place to start before delving into newer games!
