Posted: November 30, 2016
												I remember purchasing this game when it came out, and ever subsequent expansion pack and sequel. From the beginning, RCT invites you to take full control of a world of theme parks and encourages you to not only manage a successful business, but to design the coasters of your dreams along with a great selection of theming, scenery, music and other fun rides. While RCT2 added much more control of scenery and added a lot of new rides, its merely another expansion for this one (in my opinion).  For the time, the isometric graphics were great and many games since have copied the Railroad/RC Tycoon game's ability to easily convey to the user how things should look. While not incredibly realistic, the game does introduce you to other parts of the world and how they view theme parks and attractions. It wasn't until this game's release did I ever hear about free admission to parks and paying for riding the rides, but thats how a lot places in Europe go about it. By the way, this team was based out of the UK which is why some things are surprising for US audiences.If you're going to buy a version of this game, I highly encourage RCT2 for the added scenery and construction options as well as the Six Flags park packs. RCT 3 is also very fun, it came out not long after SIM Theme Park and SIMcoaster which (both borrowed tons from this game) and adds the ability to ride nearly every single attraction. It's still a classic to me, and I will never be able to get the music out of my head.

Posted: November 4, 2015
												Such a nostalgia trip~Definitely still holds up as an easy building/management game that's great for all ages, beginners and experts alike. There's a lot of fun to be had starting up a little park then watching it grow slowly over time as you add stalls and rides and even build your own roller coasters. I absolutely love this game and remember playing it a lot as a kid (I still have the CD laying around, but I may or may not have lost it) and its sequel RollerCoaster Tycoon 2 adds to the experience in so many lovely ways~But since I played RCT1 much, much more than 2, I have to say that this is my favorite entry to the series with the second game nearly tying. RCT 3 was an interesting jump into 3D that added quite a bit and changed things up, but you can just never beat a classic~ Plus this game works on almost any computer due to its 2D nature and sprite-art, so I'm sure it'd work on a toaster if you had the right OS.Buy the game if you like management genres, but don't expect the deepest of intricacies.

Posted: July 22, 2015
												First off it is a shame that there is no middle option for a review because this game is great and you should buy it... but it has one big flaw that lets it down hugely (skip to the bottom to see what that is if you don't want to read the whole thing.I would like to say that this is the type of game that makes you sit back and think "I havn't played a game this fun and simple and really enjoyable in years", it is made to be fun which is a word not usually heard in video gaming these days.As this is a game that you can buy on disc i will compare it to the disc version but first lets talk about the game on its own: It is a very happy game and definatly cheers me up, running a theme park is wierdly enjoyable and when you win the guests all clap for you (which is so cute, also if they are holding a balloon they let go and it fly's into the air (simply joys)), it has many different parks with a lot of variety in goals and map types, the graphics are still decent and the little sweeping activity the handmen do is very sweet, and if you are a phycopath then forcing the rides to fall off the rails makes a great explosion.Now lets start comparing Pros of Steam version: It has a lot more variety of maps includng real world parks, there are more variety of rides, making banners is fun, also (only fans of the disc version will understand) you can set the price of all the burger stand to be the same price and not have to go round changing them all.Cons of the steam version:  It may just be with my version but you can't see what the rides will look like untill they are built (except for the original rides that were on the original disc version) this is very annoying as i don't know what the ride is at all or if it will be similar to previous rides i have or if it will be too extreme for my guests. Also,  most of the new rides are far to big for any park and are too exspensive to be able to build. It is a shame that they have this variety of new ride designs but it is impossible to use this feature.If you liked the original disc version when you were younger then get this, it will be quite the nostalga ride and I look forward to seeing you at the exit saying "Rollarcoaster tycoon 1 was great!" (if you get my reference to the game)

Posted: December 25, 2016
												I had been intrigued by this game when it was new, but never bought it. Saw it for sale recently and decided to see what the fuss was all about. It was at about 11 p.m. when I decided I'd poke around with it for a couple hours before going to bed.Eventually, I decided it must be getting late so I'd better save the game and go to bed. I did, turned off the computer, turned around, and noticed daylight in the window. I looked at the clock. It was 9:30 a.m.My wife wondered what the heck had kept me from going to bed all night. I showed her the park I had made. She bought her own copy for her laptop, and has been playing it all night.On my Windows 10 desktop PC, the game ran with no problems. On her Windows Vista laptop, it had to be set to run in Windows 95 Compatibility Mode to keep it from crashing when loading a saved game. Note that I think the game runs in 256-color mode, so it probably will not display correctly in Windows 7 or Windows 8, as those operating systems handled 256-color palettes differently than earlier or later versions of Windows.

Posted: June 8, 2016
												RollerCoaster Tycoon: Deluxe is the First installment of the RollerCoaster Tycoon Franchise. This game was made I believe late 1990's or early 2000's, with pretty good graphics and programming, made by one guy (Chris Sawyer).I remember when I first started playing this game when I was 7 years old, I had no idea what I was doing, but I had fun messing around until I went bankrupt or something. Now I know how to properly manage a park, and respond to the guests' demands, as well as making sure I make a nice and steady profit.This game still holds up really well IMO, and is nice to kill some time when you got nothing to do or anything like that. The game is also very realistic, people react to what happens in the park, not entirely, but functionally. Here's to name a few things:1. If a RollerCoaster crashes (Accidentally), some people will leave the park and the ride's popularity will plumet to 0%2. A ride's intensity and price will affect whether a guest will ride it or not (Some guests like intense rides, some don't)3. When you begin building more than 3 (Good) RollerCoasters, guests will start to no longer want to pay more than $1.00 for less thrilling rides.Just to name some things---(Also, Employees get paid less than minumum wage on this game, so be glad you don't live in a RollerCoaster Tycoon world, or you'll be living with $35-$50 a month)Overall, it's a good gameIf you like RollerCoasters, Tycoons, and CHEAP games, then give this one a try.

Posted: November 26, 2016
												With the new Planet Coasters game and the latest RollerCoaster Tycoon having just been released, I felt some nostalgia to go back and play a bit of this one. I played it a lot years ago, an it's still a great game to this day. This game really sets the standard for a park sim. It's approachable for a new player to just go in and start throwing coasters and other rides around, but you will quickly realize the level of depth there is to the park management. From keeping eye on customer satisfaction with pricing per ride, to promotions to increase interest in your park, this game packs some fine details for being the first release in the series. If you're not sure you're into park sims, this is a great place to start before delving into newer games!

Posted: December 31, 2016
												Man, what a deal this is -- I paid $50 or so for this when it was new over a decade ago, and then bought the expansions separately after that. Fast forward to now and while I can find the discs, they're scratched up and my computer won't read them properly half the time. I got this for $2.49 on sale and it is very much worth that price. Hell, I'd say it's worth ten times that when you look at the amount of scenarios and content this game has.For the uninitiated, you build a theme park... sometimes from scratch, sometimes adding on to an existing park. Some scenarios require you to have a certain amount of guests, a certain park rating, or increase the value of the park by a certain amount before a year or more has passed in the game. There are dozens of attractions, coasters, rides, and shops to place into your park and quite a few besides just the roller coasters allow you to construct a ride of your own design (other "build your own" rides include a boat hire, train, monorail, car ride, log flume, and water slides), and there are a dozen or so types of coasters on top of that.Building and running a successful park is a balancing act of proper pricing, layout, marketing, and well-designed custom rides. You can't just make a coaster with a 90 foot drop that sends your patrons through all kinds of madness at 80 mph -- they won't get on it because it's too scary. A successful coaster has lots of different elements (hills, banked turns, helixes, tunnels, loops, and what have you), goes through those elements at the proper speed, and has scenery and theming that add to the ride's excitement (like rushing through a row of trees after a big drop, or a loop that has a track going through it).I feel like I could talk about this game forever... in short, if you like building things, buy this game. If you like theme park sims, buy this game. If you are put off by the dated graphics (which still look pretty darn good to me), buy this game anyway and be surprised at the depth and amount of content there is.I can't recommend this game enough.

Posted: December 11, 2016
												A must-play classic. Many would say its sequel RCT2 is superior with more rides, scenery, scenario editor etc, but RCT1 has the vastly better learning curve and scenario structure. The challenges are more interesting and is a much better sense of progression over the sequels. While in RCT2 you are often presented with empty landscapes to build a fresh park, most of the RCT1 scenarios involve picking up an existing park (with a few really cool starting rides) and fixing its unique problems.The challenge progression also takes you through the history of theme park rides (up until the late 90s). The first available rides tend to be wooden or small coasters, but eventually you are introduced to the 70s classic Arrows and Schwartzkopfs, and the later parks include the more modern (at the time) B&Ms.

												Oh, Rollercoaster Tycoon. My childhood in all of it's glory of crashing train cars, dirty parks, and stupidly easy to obtain profits. It's stupid fun even now, over fifteen years after it's initial release. I just wish I didn't have to mess with my resolution settings every time I wanted to play.
